questions.text: A 3466-g (7-lb, 10-oz) female newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 7 and 8, at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has a history of schizophrenia and was treated with lithium until 5 weeks' gestation, when she found out that she was pregnant. The mother was treated for alcohol use disorder 2 years ago. She has been sober for 14 months now. Examination shows that the child has micrognathia, a broad nasal bridge, a short philtrum, and small, low-set ears. Examination of the mouth shows a cleft palate. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur can be heard over the left sternal border. Echocardiography shows a single overriding great vessel arising from the heart. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Low levels of parathyroid hormone in serum
Deletion at chromosome 7 on FISH studies
Double bubble sign on abdominal x-ray
Elongated tricuspid valve leaflets on echocardiography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Streak gonads are the atretic ovarian follicles seen in Turner syndrome. Other typical features of Turner syndrome are short stature, webbed neck, and a flat chest with broadly spaced nipples. Micrognathia and cleft palate, as seen in this patient, are not typical features. Turner syndrome would also be more likely present with a bicuspid aortic valve or coarctation of the aorta than a single overriding great vessel.

B) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation of DiGeorge syndrome is variable. Facial abnormalities are common and include micrognathia, cleft palate, a broad nasal bridge, a short philtrum, and low-set ears. Additionally, DiGeorge syndrome is associated with a variety of cardiac defects, including the otherwise rare truncus arteriosus defect (single overriding vessel seen on echocardiography). DiGeorge syndrome also involves impaired development of the parathyroid glands, leading to hypoparathyroidism and hypocalcemia, which may lead to tetany and seizures during infancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Williams syndrome, which is caused by a deletion on chromosome 7, is characterized by intellectual disability and facial features such as a broad forehead, wide mouth, full cheeks and lips, and a long, smooth philtrum, none of which are present in this patient. Among the cardiac malformations associated with Williams syndrome, supravalvular aortic stenosis is the most common, which would cause a systolic ejection murmur but not a single great overriding vessel.

D) INCORRECT:

The radiographic double bubble sign is seen in patients with duodenal atresia and is a gastrointestinal finding often seen in Down syndrome (DS). Although this patient has some features of DS, such as small, low-set ears and a broad nasal bridge, she does not have the typical single palmar crease and oblique eye fissures. Furthermore, DS is associated with a variety of heart defects, most commonly atrioventricular septal defect, and rarely manifests with a single overriding great vessel on echocardiography.

E) INCORRECT:

Cri-du-chat syndrome involves anomalies similar to those seen in this patient, specifically hypertelorism, micrognathia, and low-set ears. The distinguishing characteristic is the high-pitched, cat-like cry heard in newborns, which is not present in this patient. Additionally, cri-du-chat syndrome is most commonly associated with ventricular septal defects, which would present with a holosystolic murmur rather than an ejection murmur. Even more importantly, a single great overriding vessel is more consistent with a truncus arteriosus defect.

F) INCORRECT:

The use of lithium during pregnancy can cause a variety of congenital defects, including Ebstein anomaly. Individuals with Ebstein anomaly typically present with a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border, and echocardiography would show right atrial enlargement, elongation of the tricuspid valve leaflets, and tricuspid regurgitation, none of which is seen here.

G) INCORRECT:

Bilateral cataracts in a neonate are typical of congenital rubella syndrome, which often also causes bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and cardiac defects, most commonly patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). However, a PDA would cause a continuous machine-like murmur, unlike the systolic ejection murmur audible in this patient. Furthermore, a PDA would have been detectable on echocardiography because it results in abnormal blood flow.
questions.hint: A chest x-ray of this neonate would show an absent thymic shadow.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and cough for one week. The mother reports that her son has difficulty breathing. He has also had a generalized skin rash for the past 4 days. His symptoms began shortly after returning from a trip to India. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Examination shows small, erythematous pustules with hemorrhagic necrosis over the trunk and shoulders and generalized lymphadenopathy. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin. An x-ray of the chest shows small 1–4 mm pulmonary nodules scattered throughout the lungs, and a right-sided pleural effusion with interstitial infiltrates. Blood smear shows acid-fast bacilli. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Absent B cells with normal T cell count
Decreased T-cell receptor excision circles on PCR
Low serum IgG, IgA, and IgM levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Isolated low serum IgA levels are suggestive of selective IgA deficiency, the most common primary immunodeficiency. Although recurrent respiratory infections, sinusitis, or chronic diarrhea may occur, many affected individuals are asymptomatic or have a protracted, yet mild disease course. This child's previously unremarkable medical history and sudden onset of severe disease cannot be explained by selective IgA deficiency and is indicative of a much more severe immunodeficiency.

B) CORRECT:

Decreased IFN-γ levels are diagnostic of IL-12 receptor deficiency. Activated antigen-presenting macrophages typically release IL-12, which triggers T-helper cells to transform to T1 type. T1-helper cells subsequently release IFN-γ to activate macrophages. If IL-12 receptors on naive T cells are defective, macrophages cannot be activated by IFN-γ to trigger cytotoxicity in cells infected with intracellular pathogens, such as mycobacteria and salmonella. The initial presentation in patients with IL-12 receptor deficiency includes disseminated disease, sepsis, and DIC. This child's history of recent travel to India, acid-fast bacilli on the blood smear (indicating mycobacterial bacteremia), and involvement of several organs (lungs, liver, skin, lymphatic system) are consistent with a disseminated tuberculosis infection due to IL-12 receptor deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the WAS gene is the cause of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which is characterized by impaired T-cell function and thrombocytopenia. Affected children often present with a triad of eczema, thrombocytopenic purpura, and recurrent opportunistic infections within the first years of life. Although the infection seen in this child could occur in patients with WAS as well, the absence of previous infections, purpura, and eczema make it unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Absent B cells with a normal T-cell count are detected in individuals with X-linked agammaglobulinemia (i.e., Bruton-agammaglobulinemia), an X-linked recessive disorder that exclusively affects boys and causes a complete deficiency of B lymphocytes. Unlike this patient's case, though, affected children have a history of recurring (usually pyogenic) infections (e.g., otitis media, pneumonia) starting after 6 months of age, which is when transplacental IgG-mediated passive immunity subsides.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased parathyroid hormone levels together with low Ca2+ levels and a reduced absolute T-lymphocyte count are diagnostic of DiGeorge syndrome. Affected patients present with a specific set of symptoms (CATCH-22), which are absent in this patient. Although an increased susceptibility for infections results from thymic aplasia, these are primarily viral or fungal, not bacterial (like that of this patient as indicated by his blood smear).
Image Description:

Broad nasal bridge and nasal tip, ocular hypertelorism, dysplastic and low-set ears as well as micrognathia.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased T-cell receptor excision circles (TRECs) on PCR are diagnostic of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Various, simultaneous genetic mutations result in a severe reduction of both the number and functionality of T cells and B cells. Affected infants appear healthy at birth but present with severe, recurrent infections within a few months after birth and failure to thrive. Common infections include bacterial diarrhea, chronic candidiasis, as well as viral and protozoal infections. These features do not apply to this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Low serum IgG, IgA, and IgM levels are detected in individuals with common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), which only affects B cells. The disorder manifests with recurrent pyogenic respiratory infections and is associated with an increased risk for lymphoma, gastric cancer, and autoimmune disorders (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis). Unlike many other congenital immunodeficiency disorders that present in children, CVID has an age of onset of 20–35 years and does not manifest in children.
questions.hint: This previously healthy child, who was most likely exposed to tuberculosis (TB) during travel, has symptoms of disseminated TB (cough, generalized rash with hemorrhagic necrosis, generalized lymphadenopathy, and miliary nodules on x-ray). These findings raise concern for an IL-12 receptor deficiency, a congenital T-cell immunodeficiency.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent skin lesions. The lesions first appeared at the age of 2 months and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. He has also had several episodes of respiratory tract infections, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent fevers since birth. The boy attends daycare. His older brother has asthma. Immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. He appears ill. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows several raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groin, and extremities; some secrete pus. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with Bruton agammaglobulinemia (XLA) present with recurrent, severe pyogenic infections (pneumonia, otitis media), and hypoplasia of the tonsils and other lymphoid tissues, due to very low levels of B cells. While this patient has recurrent infections, he lacks tonsillar hypoplasia. Also, skin infections are not common in XLA, and this patient has had respiratory tract infections and recurrent fever since birth. Infections in XLA typically occur from 6 months onwards, when passive immunity from transplacental maternal IgG expires.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

B) CORRECT:

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to impaired function of phagocytic cells, resulting in recurrent bacterial and fungal infections in early childhood. The nitroblue tetrazolium test used to be the gold standard to test phagocytic oxidase activity, but it has been widely replaced by the dihydrorhodamine test. Treatment consists of prophylactic antibiotics (daily TMP-SMX), interferon‑γ, and glucocorticoids to prevent and treat severe infections; bone marrow transplant is the definitive treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Although patients with ataxia-telangiectasia can also present with immunocompromise and infections, other clinical features such as progressive ataxia, telangiectasias, and malignancies (e.g., leukemia, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, gastric carcinoma) are missing in this patient.
Image Description:

Medial angle of the left eye showing severely dilated blood vessels on the conjunctiva (conjunctival telangiectasia).

Conjunctival telangiectasias are a clinical finding of ataxia telangiectasia (Louis-Bar syndrome), a rare neurocutaneous syndrome

D) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a very common skin disease. Although this patient's brother has an associated condition (asthma), the rash in atopic dermatitis is usually dry, scaly, and intensely pruritic. Also, this child appears ill, has lymphadenopathy, and has had several episodes of respiratory tract infections and recurrent fever since birth, which are not associated with atopic dermatitis.
Image Description:

Ill-defined, erythematous macules with excoriation (due to scratching) can be seen on the flexural surface of the knee.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) may also present with recurrent infections (e.g., otitis media) and skin lesions during their first year of life. However, this patient's skin abnormality is not consistent with purpura or eczema. Remember the mnemonic for WAS: WIPE (Wiskott-Aldrich, Infections, Purpura, Eczema).

F) INCORRECT:

Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS) may also present with recurrent (usually pyogenic) infections. However, other features of CHS such as bleeding abnormalities, albinism, and neurologic dysfunction are missing in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurring respiratory infections, lymphadenopathy, and inflammatory, pustular lesions, starting at a very young age. These features together suggest impaired functioning of phagocytic cells, making him especially susceptible to infection with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., S. aureus, E. coli, Aspergillus).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of persistent fever and cough. Three days ago, he was diagnosed with pneumonia and acute otitis media. He was started on ampicillin-sulbactam and clarithromycin, but his symptoms did not improve. The mother reports that her son has been hospitalized 3 times due to pneumonia. He was first diagnosed with pneumonia at the age of 10 months. She also reports several episodes of bilateral otitis media and recurrent respiratory tract infections. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Otoscopic examination shows purulent otorrhea bilaterally. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds over both lung fields. The palatine tonsils and adenoids are hypoplastic. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defective NADPH oxidase causes chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which can also lead to recurrent infections. However, patients with CGD often have skin manifestations (recurrent skin infections and an eczematous rash) and symptoms due to granulomas of the gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts (e.g., abdominal pain, bladder distention).

B) INCORRECT:

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD) results from a deficiency of beta-2 integrin, a protein responsible for leukocyte chemotaxis. Although LAD also causes recurrent infections, they tend to be nonsuppurative skin and soft tissue infections. In addition, there is no reported history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord, which is a common feature of LAD.

C) INCORRECT:

An impaired IL-2R gamma chain is the most common cause of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Children with SCID appear normal at birth but progressively develop recurrent, severe infections (including bacterial, fungal, viral, or protozoal) and show failure to thrive. SCID typically causes more severe infections than those seen in this patient and often causes death within the first year of life if not diagnosed and treated during infancy.

D) INCORRECT:

A defect in the ATM gene is the cause of ataxia-telangiectasia, a neurocutaneous disorder that can cause immunodeficiency in children. However, in a 3-year-old child, it would also typically present with ataxia and telangiectasias of the face and conjunctiva. In addition, this condition would not explain this patient's hypoplastic lymphoid tissue, making it an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the WAS gene causes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which can cause recurrent infections. Unlike this patient, however, children with WAS present with eczema and thrombocytopenic purpura in addition to recurrent infections. Moreover, WAS would not explain this patient's hypoplastic lymphoid tissue.

F) CORRECT:

X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) is caused by a defect in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene, a signal transduction molecule found on B cells. Without this molecule, proper B-cell maturation cannot occur, resulting in a severe reduction in plasma cells and immunoglobulins. Although recurrent infections can be a feature of many immunodeficiency disorders, tonsillar hypoplasia (due to low B-cell volume) is suggestive of XLA. The diagnosis is confirmed with flow cytometry showing reduced levels of B cells and normal levels of T cells. Treatment for XLA consists of IVIG and prophylactic antibiotics.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent, severe pyogenic infections (pneumonia, otitis media) and lymphoid tissue hypoplasia. His first episode of pneumonia occurred > 6 months after birth. These features suggest X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia.

questions.text:
A 13-month-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of rectal bleeding that occurred earlier that morning. The patient has also had several itchy and red skin lesions that started on his scalp and spread downwards. His parents report that he has had six episodes of bilateral otitis media since birth. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 3rd percentile for height and weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several eczematous lesions over the scalp, neck, and upper and lower extremities, as well as multiple red spots that do not blanch on pressure. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
11,500/mm3



Platelet count
30,000/mm3


Prothrombin time
14 sec


Partial thromboplastin time
33 sec


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) type 1 may present with recurrent infections during childhood. However, affected children usually demonstrate significant leukocytosis (due to severe neutrophilia). Patients would also have a history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord stump and/or impaired wound healing.

B) INCORRECT:

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) may present with recurrent infections (e.g., otitis media), failure to thrive, and cutaneous candidal infections, which may be mistaken for eczematous rash. However, SCID is quite severe and invariably presents during the first few months of life with pneumonia, persistent diarrhea, and sepsis. Without immune reconstitution therapy, children usually die before the end of the first year (with almost all children dying before the end of the second year). This child has a less severe primary immune deficiency syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) may manifest in early childhood with anemia (due to chronic disease) and recurrent infections. However, recurrent pneumonia, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, and/or perianal abscesses caused by catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus, Serratia, Klebsiella, and Aspergillus are more common than recurrent otitis media. Thrombocytopenia and rectal bleeding are not manifestations of CGD.

D) INCORRECT:

DiGeorge syndrome may manifest in early childhood with recurrent otitis media (due to T-cell abnormalities and velopharyngeal insufficiency) and failure to thrive. However, examination would typically reveal facial dysmorphism, a cleft palate, and/or a murmur (due to a congenital heart defect). Patients would also have a history of twitching, seizures, and/or tetany (due to hypocalcemia caused by primary hypoparathyroidism) and poor feeding (due to a congenital heart defect, cleft palate, and/or hypocalcemia).
Image Description:

Broad nasal bridge and nasal tip, ocular hypertelorism, dysplastic and low-set ears as well as micrognathia.

E) INCORRECT:

Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS) may present with recurrent pyogenic infections as well as bleeding diathesis. However, oculocutaneous albinism would be evident. Also, the bleeding manifestations in the early stages of CHS are due to a platelet storage pool deficiency and not platelet deficiency; as such, platelet counts would be normal and bleeding manifestations are typically mild (e.g., easy bruisability). Moreover, pyogenic infections in CHS more commonly affect the gingiva, skin, and lungs; recurrent periodontal infections, pyoderma gangrenosum, and/or bacterial pneumonia are therefore more common manifestations than recurrent otitis media.

Severe bleeding manifestations as well as severe thrombocytopenia may occur in CHS during an “accelerated phase” (as a result of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis), which can occur at any age. However, patients in this phase would also have hepatosplenomegaly, evidence of hepatic dysfunction (e.g., jaundice, prolonged PT), lymphadenopathy, fever, and/or leukopenia, none of which are present in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Patients with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) have an X-linked mutation in the gene encoding for the WAS protein, which results in impaired actin cytoskeleton reorganization of lymphocytes (especially T cells) and platelets. Impaired T-cell function increases the risk of recurrent infections (e.g., otitis media). In the early stages, thrombocytopenia is caused by increased platelet destruction in the spleen. A combination of thrombocytopenia and intrinsic platelet defects result in purpura and recurrent rectal bleeding with anemia due to blood loss. The mechanism causing eczema, another classic feature of WAS, is unknown, but it is probably the result of a hyperallergic state associated with increased IgE levels. Failure to thrive is a common manifestation of most primary immunodeficiency disorders that affect T lymphocytes.

Patients with WAS are also at increased risk of developing autoimmune diseases (e.g., autoimmune hemolytic anemia, arthritis) and childhood hematological malignancies (e.g., lymphoma, leukemia). Treatment includes supportive therapy in the form of regular IVIG infusions, adequate nutrition, platelet transfusions for bleeding episodes, and early treatment of eczema. Definitive therapy is stem cell transplantation. For patients who cannot undergo definitive treatment and have recurrent episodes of severe thrombocytopenia, splenectomy may be considered. Patients who develop autoimmune complications require systemic steroids with high doses of IVIG.
questions.hint: The constellation of thrombocytopenia, eczema, recurrent infections, and failure to thrive is consistent with a particular X-linked recessive disorder.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of fever and a cough for 3 days. His mother reports that he has had multiple episodes of loose stools over the past 3 months. He has been treated for otitis media 4 times and bronchiolitis 3 times during the past 3 months. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and the neonatal period was uncomplicated. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 3rd percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 126/min, and respirations are 35/min. Examination shows an erythematous scaly rash over the trunk and extremities. There are white patches on the tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped. Inspiratory crackles are heard in the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows an infiltrate in the right lower lobe and an absent thymic shadow. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

DiGeorge syndrome can cause recurrent opportunistic infections due to T-cell deficiency. The thymus in affected patients is absent or hypoplastic, which results in an absent thymic shadow on chest x-ray. However, patients with DiGeorge syndrome have facial anomalies (such as a prominent nasal bridge, dysplastic ears, or micrognathia). The absence of a murmur (due to congenital heart defects) and tetany (due to hypocalcemia) make this diagnosis even less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) can lead to eczematous rash and recurrent infections due to dysfunctional T cells. However, the third component of the classic WAS triad, microthrombocytopenia, is not seen here. In addition, WAS rarely leads to the number and severity of infections seen in this patient and does not explain the absent thymic shadow, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is a congenital disorder characterized by severe, recurrent infections (e.g., bacterial diarrhea, oral candidiasis, respiratory tract infections) and failure to thrive. Patients with SCID often have an absent lymphoid tissue (no thymic shadow on chest x-ray, no tonsils or lymph nodes). Recurrent eczematous rashes are also seen. Most US states offer a newborn screening program for SCID that utilizes PCR amplification of T-cell receptor circles (TRECs). For infants with suspected SCID, the diagnosis is confirmed by a low T-cell count and a mutation of the IL2RG or adenosine deaminase genes.

Patients with SCID should be treated with immune reconstitution therapy (IVIG administration), PCP prophylaxis, and protective isolation. Definitive therapy involves hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). If untreated, the disease is usually fatal in the first year of life. Successful HSCT significantly improves the prognosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) can cause recurrent pyogenic respiratory infections, similar to those seen in this case. However, it is typically diagnosed after puberty and is not usually seen in a 5-month-old infant. In addition, CVID does not explain this patient's absent thymic shadow. Rather, patients would present with hypertrophic adenoids, lymphadenopathy, and/or splenomegaly.

E) INCORRECT:

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) can cause recurrent pulmonary infections such as those seen in this patient. However, patients with LAD usually have a history of delayed umbilical cord separation, which is not seen here. In addition, LAD does not lead to an absent thymic shadow, making it an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Selective IgA deficiency is the most common primary immunodeficiency and may cause recurrent pulmonary and gastrointestinal infections. However, oral candidiasis and skin infections are rarely seen in this condition. In addition, selective IgA deficiency would not explain this child's absent thymic shadow.

G) INCORRECT:

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) can lead to recurrent, severe infections similar to those seen in this patient. However, it does not explain this child's absent thymic shadow, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) causes recurrent infections due to B-cell dysfunction. However, it does not explain the absent thymic shadow on chest x-ray.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

I) INCORRECT:

Chediak-Higashi syndrome can cause recurrent infections similar to those seen in this patient. However, it also results in oculocutaneous albinism and mild bleeding diathesis, which are not seen here. In addition, Chediak-Higashi syndrome does not explain this patient's absent thymic shadow.
questions.hint: Adenosine deaminase deficiency is an autosomal recessive form of this disease.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of difficulty breathing for the past hour. The parents report noisy breathing and bluish discoloration of their son's lips. During the past two months, the patient has had several upper respiratory tract infections and poor weight gain. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 20th percentile for length and 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Crackles are heard over both lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Intubation is performed and methylprednisolone is administered. Methenamine silver staining of bronchial lavage fluid shows aggregates of 2 to 8 cysts with central spores. Serum IgA titers are decreased. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defect in the WAS gene is responsible for Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, which can present during infancy with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, Pneumocystis pneumonia, and failure to thrive. However, patients with WAS typically have bleeding manifestations such as rectal bleeding, eczematous skin lesions (due to atopic dermatitis), and increased, rather than decreased, IgA titers.

B) CORRECT:

A defective CD40 ligand is the mechanism underlying type 1 hyper-IgM syndrome. A defect in the CD40 ligand renders T cells unable to switch IgM production in B cells to the production of other immunoglobulins (e.g., IgA, IgG, IgE), resulting in decreased IgA titers, as seen here, and decreased humoral immunity. The CD40 ligand defect also results in an inability of T cells to upregulate cells that express the CD40 molecule (e.g., B cells, macrophages, dendritic cells). Since these cells also happen to be cells that present antigens to T cells, the net effects are a decreased antigen-specific T-cell response and decreased cell-mediated immunity, which in turn increase the risk of infection by pathogens such as Pneumocystis. The onset of symptoms in type 1 hyper IgM syndrome can occur during early infancy and failure to thrive may occur as a result of recurrent infections.

Other pathogens that infect patients with type 1 hyper-IgM syndrome with an increased frequency include Cryptosporidium parvum and Histoplasmosis. C. parvum enteritis results in chronic diarrhea, which can exacerbate failure to thrive. C. parvum also infects the biliary tract and leads to an increased risk of cirrhosis and cholangiocarcinoma. Patients are treated with IVIG injections (immune reconstitution therapy) and PCP prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Definitive therapy involves hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

C) INCORRECT:

Dysfunction of the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST) is the pathophysiology underlying Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS), which may also result in recurrent sinopulmonary infections. However, other features, such as oculocutaneous albinism and/or ocular motility disorders (e.g., strabismus, nystagmus), would also be present. Furthermore, Pneumocystis pneumonia is more common with primary T-cell defects. Patients with CHS tend to present instead with infections by pyogenic organisms such as S. aureus.

D) INCORRECT:

A defect in the Bruton tyrosine kinase gene (BTK) is responsible for X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which may also result in decreased IgA titers and recurrent sinopulmonary infections by extracellular organisms such as S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae. Although Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) may rarely occur in XLA, P. jirovecii is an intracellular pathogen, and PCP is therefore more common in primary immunodeficiencies with T-cell defects. Moreover, it is uncommon for patients to develop symptoms before the age of 6 months because infants generally retain passively acquired maternal antibodies until this age.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

E) INCORRECT:

A microdeletion in chromosome 22 is seen in DiGeorge syndrome, which can also present in early infancy with Pneumocystis pneumonia, recurrent sinopulmonary infections, and a failure to thrive. DiGeorge syndrome may also result in profound central cyanosis due to conotruncal anomalies (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot, pulmonary atresia). However, patients with DiGeorge syndrome would typically have facial dysmorphism (e.g., micrognathia), a cleft palate, and/or a murmur, as well as a history of twitching, seizures, and/or tetany (due to hypocalcemia caused by primary hypoparathyroidism).
Image Description:

Broad nasal bridge and nasal tip, ocular hypertelorism, dysplastic and low-set ears as well as micrognathia.

F) INCORRECT:

Defective NADPH oxidase results in chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which may manifest during infancy with recurrent sinopulmonary infections. However, pneumonia caused by catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus, Serratia, Klebsiella, and Aspergillus is far more common than Pneumocystis pneumonia. Pneumocystis pneumonia is more common in primary immunodeficiencies with T-cell defects rather than CGD, which only affects neutrophil function. Other pathognomonic features of CGD are GI obstruction or urinary retention caused by granulomas, which are not seen here.
questions.hint: This patient's current infection is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii (cysts with central spores on methenamine silver staining), which suggests a defect in cell-mediated immunity. A decreased serum IgA level suggests an additional defect in humoral immunity. The diagnosis is therefore a mixed congenital immunodeficiency disorder, most likely hyper-IgM syndrome.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of fever, difficulty breathing, and coughing for the past week. In the past year, he has had four sinus infections, three upper respiratory tract infections, and an episode of severe bronchiolitis requiring hospitalization. Since birth, he has had multiple episodes of oral thrush treated with nystatin, as well as chronic diarrhea and failure to thrive. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 38/min, and blood pressure is 106/63 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Auscultation of the lungs shows bilateral crackles and wheezing. Examination shows a prominent nasal bridge, a hypoplastic wing of the nose, a shortened chin, and dysplastic ears. A nasopharyngeal aspirate test for respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is positive. This patient most likely has a deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with B-cell deficiency have impaired humoral immunity, which leads to recurrent bacterial, not viral and fungal, infections. Common B-cell disorders include Bruton agammaglobulinemia, selective IgA deficiency, and common variable immunodeficiency. In Bruton agammaglobulinemia, patients usually present with recurrent bacterial infections after 6 months of age when maternal antibodies are no longer present and patients have absent or scanty lymph nodes and tonsils.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with terminal complement deficiency (C5–C9) are unable to form membrane attack complexes, which leads to recurrent pyogenic, bacterial infections with Neisseria (N. gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis). This patient has recurrent viral and fungal infections and has no history of neonatal conjunctivitis, genitourinary infections, or meningitis.

C) CORRECT:

T cells are an important part of cell-mediated immunity, which is especially vital to viral and fungal immunity. This patient has had multiple episodes of oral fungal infection with Candida albicans, is infected with RSV, and has had recurrent respiratory tract infections. Common T-cell disorders include DiGeorge syndrome, Job syndrome, IL-12 receptor deficiency, and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis. Since this child presents with dysmorphic facial features, DiGeorge syndrome is likely the underlying cause of his immunodeficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Selective IgA deficiency is the most common primary immunodeficiency. It may manifest with recurrent airway and gastrointestinal infections, as well as chronic diarrhea, because IgA plays an essential role in mucosal immunity. However, individuals with selective IgA deficiency are often asymptomatic. Furthermore, oral thrush is uncommon. Finally, other manifestations of selective IgA deficiency, such as atopy, autoimmune disease, and anaphylactic transfusion reaction, are not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with IL-12 receptor deficiency usually present early in childhood with disseminated salmonella and/or nontuberculosis mycobacterial infections. This patient has no history of either infection to suggest this immunodeficiency. Additionally, since this child presents with dysmorphic facial features, DiGeorge syndrome is likely the underlying cause of his immunodeficiency.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with B-cell and T-cell deficiency have impaired humoral and cell-mediated immunity. Associated disorders include severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), ataxia telangiectasia, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, and hyper-IgM syndrome. Patients with SCID become severely ill shortly after birth with recurrent infections of all types (viral, bacterial, fungal, and protozoan), not only viral and fungal infections. Most patients will not survive the first year of life without hematopoietic cell transplantation, which makes SCID unlikely in this 2-year old child.

G) INCORRECT:

In patients with leukocyte-adhesion deficiency, migration of leukocytes into extravascular sites of inflammation is impaired, leading to recurrent bacterial (not fungal or viral) skin and mucosal infections without pus formation and impaired wound healing. Furthermore, there is usually a history of omphalitis in the neonatal period with delayed separation (> 30 days) of the umbilical cord stump due to insufficient healing, which has not been reported in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of multiple and chronic infections that are likely caused by viral and fungal pathogens. His facial features are consistent with DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of fever for the past 3 days. They also state that he has been less active and has been refusing to eat. The patient has had two episodes of bilateral otitis media since birth. He was born at term and had severe respiratory distress and sepsis shortly after birth that was treated with antibiotics. Umbilical cord separation occurred at the age of 33 days. The patient appears pale. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 195/min, and blood pressure is 60/40 mm Hg. He is at the 25th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Examination shows a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. Oral examination shows white mucosal patches that bleed when they are scraped off. There is bilateral mucoid, nonpurulent ear discharge. Several scaly erythematous skin lesions are seen on the chest. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 38,700/mm3 with 90% neutrophils and a platelet count of 200,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defect in the Bruton tyrosine kinase gene (BTK) is responsible for X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which may result in recurrent otitis media from infection with extracellular bacteria such as S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae. However, delayed umbilical cord separation is not expected. Moreover, candidiasis is more commonly seen with defects involving T cells and granulocytes rather than in isolated primary defects of antibody production such as XLA.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

B) INCORRECT:

A defective CD40 ligand is the underlying mechanism of type 1 hyper-IgM syndrome. The onset of type 1 hyper-IgM syndrome is in the first 2 years of life and the condition would result in recurrent infections. However, neutropenia rather than neutrophilia is typically seen, and patients often show failure to thrive. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

A defect in the interleukin-2 receptor subunit gamma gene (IL2RG) is the most common mutation associated with severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID), which presents soon after birth with sepsis, recurrent episodes of otitis media, and mucocutaneous candidiasis. However, failure to thrive and a history of chronic diarrhea would typically be present, and a CBC would reveal a low absolute lymphocyte count. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.

D) CORRECT:

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD1) is caused by an autosomal recessive defect in CD18, a subunit of beta-2 integrin, which results in an inability of leukocytes to migrate to the site of infection. Patients subsequently have recurrent infections and a characteristic absence of pus with infection. Other characteristic features of the condition include poor wound healing with large skin ulcers, omphalitis, and severe periodontitis/gingivitis. A very high neutrophil count (as high as 100,000/mm3 during active infection) is seen as neutrophil activation and recruitment of neutrophils occurs, but neutrophils are unable to extravasate into tissues, causing pooling within the circulation.

E) INCORRECT:

Defective NADPH oxidase results in chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which may manifest during infancy with candidiasis (since C. albicans is catalase-positive) and neutrophilia during episodes of infection. However, recurrent pneumonia, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, and/or perianal abscesses caused by catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus are far more common than recurrent otitis media. Moreover, these infections tend to remain localized and sepsis is not as common as in other primary immune deficiency syndromes. Other pathognomonic features of CGD are GI obstruction and urinary retention caused by granulomas. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

A loss of function of the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST) is the underlying pathophysiology of Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS), which results in recurrent infections such as S. aureus pneumonia. However, patients with CHS would have neutropenia, not neutrophilia. Other features would also be present, such as oculocutaneous albinism and/or ocular motility disorders (e.g., strabismus, nystagmus). Delayed umbilical cord separation would not be expected.

G) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the WAS gene is the underlying cause of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which can present during infancy with recurrent otitis media as well as scaly erythematous lesions due to atopic dermatitis. However, the absence of thrombocytopenia on a CBC essentially rules out WAS. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of septic shock (fever, hypotension, tachycardia, decreased peripheral perfusion), bilateral nonpurulent otitis media, mucocutaneous candidiasis (white mucosal patches that bleed when scraped), and a history of recurrent bacterial infections. This presentation in combination with delayed umbilical cord separation (> 30 days postpartum) suggests a specific congenital phagocyte disorder.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of fever and a cough for 3 days. He was treated for otitis media 3 and 4 months ago. He was also treated for pneumococcal pneumonia and H. influenzae meningitis this past month. He was delivered at term. Pregnancy and neonatal period were uncomplicated. He was exclusively breast-fed until 6 months of age. He has a maternal uncle who died of recurrent respiratory tract infections at 28 years of age. He is at the 20th percentile for height and the 10th percentile for weight. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 122/min, and respirations are 44/min. Examination shows crackles at the left lung base. Palatine tonsils are absent. An x-ray shows an infiltrate in the left lower lung lobe. Flow cytometry shows absence of B-cells. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the late onset of symptoms in this patient?

choices.text: Reduced T-cell receptor excision circles by 6 months
Involution of the thymus begins at 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Breast milk and colostrum provide IgA antibodies (i.e., passive immunity) to the infant. Patients with Bruton agammaglobulinemia have deficient IgA levels (due to impaired B-cell maturation), which may worsen after weaning from breastfeeding. However, IgA plays a minor role in humoral defense (e.g., most patients with IgA deficiencies are asymptomatic), and loss of passive IgA immunity would not explain his serious bacterial infections (i.e., meningitis, pneumonia).

B) INCORRECT:

Reduced T-cell receptor excision circles, a marker for impaired T-cell maturation, suggest SCID. Patients with SCID have recurrent infections of all pathogen types (viral, bacterial, fungal, and protozoan) with failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, and thrush. This patient's recurrent bacterial infections beginning at 6-months old are more consistent with Bruton agammaglobulinemia. B-cell maturation, not T-cell maturation, is dysfunctional in Bruton agammaglobulinemia, due to a mutation in the B-cell tyrosine kinase gene.

C) INCORRECT:

Thymus involution is a normal age-related process that is not associated with Bruton agammaglobulinemia. Furthermore, the thymus plays an important role in T-cell, not B-cell maturation, the latter of which is impaired in Bruton agammaglobulinemia and causes recurrent bacterial infections, as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Functional asplenia (due to splenic infarctions) is one consequence of sickle cell anemia, and places these patients at increased risk for severe infections with encapsulated organisms (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae), as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks any other features of sickle cell disease (e.g., dactylitis, pain crises). Although the spleen plays an important role in antibody production by B-cells, the B-cells themselves are dysfunctional in Bruton agammaglobulinemia.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with Bruton agammaglobulinemia have impaired B-cell maturation and antibody production, resulting in recurrent bacterial infections. However, patients are asymptomatic until 4–6 months of age, when passive immunity is no longer present (i.e., maternal IgG antibodies that were acquired through placental transfer are metabolized and antibody titers decline gradually). Treatment consists of monthly IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) infusions to replace antibody deficiencies and antibiotics for bacterial infections.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase
questions.hint: Recurrent bacterial infections, failure to thrive, and absent B cells on flow cytometry in a male infant with a maternal uncle with similar symptoms suggest Bruton agammaglobulinemia (X-linked agammaglobulinemia).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a generalized, pruritic rash. The rash began during infancy and did not resolve despite initiating treatment with topical corticosteroids. Three months ago, he was treated for several asymptomatic soft tissue abscesses on his legs. He has been admitted to the hospital three times during the past 2 years for pneumonia. Physical examination shows a prominent forehead and a wide nasal bridge. Examination of the skin shows a diffuse eczematous rash and white plaques on the face, scalp, and shoulders. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 6,000/mm3 with 25% eosinophils and a serum IgE concentration of 2,300 IU/mL (N = 0–380). Flow cytometry shows a deficiency of T helper 17 cells. The patient’s increased susceptibility to infection is most likely due to which of the following?

choices.text: Impaired interferon-γ secretion by Th1 cells

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Autosomal dominant hyperimmunoglobulin E syndrome (hyper-IgE syndrome) is caused by a mutation in the STAT3 gene, which leads to Th17 cell deficiency and decreased Th17-dependent production of IL-17. This results in impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, which causes decreased inflammation, cold abscesses (most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus), and increased susceptibility to sinopulmonary infections (e.g., pneumonia). In addition to this patient's findings, hyper-IgE syndrome is also associated with other skeletal abnormalities (e.g., retained baby teeth, osteopenia/osteoporosis, pathologic fractures), and decreased IFN-γ.

The eczematous rash seen in hyper-IgE syndrome is severely pruritic and may be confused with atopic dermatitis, which may also manifest with elevated IgE and recurrent superficial staphylococcal skin infections (due to breaks in the skin from dryness and scratching). Abscesses, recurrent sinopulmonary infections, and skeletal abnormalities are, however, not expected in atopic dermatitis. Furthermore, patients with hyper-IgE syndrome usually lack other features of atopy (e.g., asthma, allergies, family history).

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired DNA repair in lymphocytes is seen in ataxia telangiectasia (AT), an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to defects in the ATM gene. These defects lead to a failure to detect DNA damage and consequently, an inability to repair double-stranded DNA breaks. AT is associated with dermatologic manifestations, immune deficiency, and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. However, dermatologic manifestations include telangiectasias and cafe-au-lait spots rather than eczema. Other features include neurologic abnormalities (e.g., ataxia, cerebellar atrophy, motor weakness), which are not present in this patient. Furthermore, laboratory tests typically show IgA, IgG, and IgE deficiency and lymphopenia rather than the elevated serum IgE and eosinophilia seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired respiratory burst in neutrophils is seen in chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which is most commonly due to an X-linked recessive defect in NADPH oxidase that causes defective reactive oxygen species production. Patients with CGD may present with recurrent severe infections (e.g., skin, respiratory, bone, gastrointestinal, genitourinary tract) with catalase-positive organisms and granulomas of the skin and gastrointestinal/genitourinary tract. However, CGD would not explain this patient's eczema, increased IgE, eosinophilia, or deficiency of Th17 cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired actin assembly in lymphocytes is seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), an X-linked recessive disorder that occurs due to mutations in the WAS gene. Impaired actin cytoskeleton reorganization leads to defective antigen presentation. Patients with WAS may present with eczema, recurrent (pyogenic) sinopulmonary infections (with encapsulated pathogens), eosinophilia, and elevated serum IgE. However, WAS is not associated with Th17 deficiency or cold abscesses. Moreover, WAS usually manifests with bleeding diathesis due to microthrombocytopenia and elevated IgA, which are not seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired immunoglobulin class-switching in lymphocytes is seen in hyper IgM syndrome, an X-linked recessive disorder that most commonly occurs due to deficiency of CD40L on Th cells. Patients with hyper IgM syndrome may present with recurrent (pyogenic) sinopulmonary infections (with encapsulated pathogens). However, hyper IgM syndrome is also associated with opportunistic infections (e.g., PCP pneumonia, cryptosporidium enteritis, CMV hepatitis), which are not present in this patient. Furthermore, hyper IgM syndrome causes elevated IgM and decreased IgG, IgA, and IgE, and it would not explain this patient's eosinophilia or Th17 cell deficiency.

F) INCORRECT:

Impaired interferon-γ secretion by Th1 cells is seen in IL-12 receptor deficiency, an autosomal recessive disorder. Normally, antigen-presenting cells (e.g., macrophages) secrete IL-12, which binds to IL-12 receptors on CD4+ Th cells, inducing Th1 differentiation. Th1 cells then secrete IFN-γ, which stimulates macrophages to kill phagocytosed pathogens. Accordingly, patients with IL-12 receptor deficiency present with decreased IFN-γ as well as disseminated infections with mycobacteria (e.g., following administration of BCG vaccine), Salmonella spp., and fungi rather than the cold abscesses and sinopulmonary infections seen in this patient. Furthermore, IL-12 receptor deficiency would not explain this patient's coarse facies, eczema, elevated serum IgE, and eosinophilia.
questions.hint: In combination with his increased serum IgE, eosinophilia, and deficiency of Th17 cells, this patient's coarse facies (prominent forehead, wide nasal bridge), history of eczema, cold abscesses, and recurrent pneumonia are consistent with autosomal dominant hyperimmunoglobulin E syndrome (Job syndrome).

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of fever, fast breathing, and difficulty feeding for 2 days. His mother reports that he has had recurrent pneumonia and has been hospitalized for severe dehydration secondary to acute gastroenteritis caused by rotavirus infection three times in the past 4 months. He is at the 3rd percentile for both height and weight. Examination shows a generalized, erythematous, scaly rash and white patches on the tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates and an absent thymic shadow. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chromosome 22q11.2 microdeletion leads to DiGeorge syndrome, which can cause recurrent opportunistic infections due to T-cell deficiency. The thymus in affected patients is absent or hypoplastic, which could explain this patient's thymic shadow on chest x-ray. However, patients with DiGeorge syndrome have facial anomalies (such as a prominent nasal bridge, dysplastic ears, or micrognathia), which are not seen in this patient. The absence of a murmur (due to congenital heart defects) and tetany (due to hypocalcemia) make this diagnosis even less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

NADPH oxidase deficiency causes chronic granulomatous disease, which results in the inability of neutrophils to produce free radicals. It leads to recurrent, severe infections with catalase-positive organisms. It does not lead to recurrent fungal and viral infections or result in an absent thymic shadow.

C) INCORRECT:

Integrin beta-2 (CD18) defect causes leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD), which manifests with recurrent pulmonary infections, such as those seen in this patient. However, patients with LAD usually have a history of delayed umbilical cord separation. In addition, LAD does not lead to an absent thymic shadow.

D) INCORRECT:

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is caused by an X-linked mutation of the WAS gene, which leads to an inability of T cells to organize the actin cytoskeleton. WAS manifests with an eczematous rash and recurrent infections, as seen in this patient. However, this patient does not have thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, the third component of the classic WAS triad. In addition, WAS rarely leads to the number and severity of infections seen in this patient, nor does it lead to an absent thymic shadow.

E) CORRECT:

The IL-2 receptor gamma chain (common gamma chain) is a receptor subunit of several cytokines (e.g., IL-2, IL-4, IL-7) that are involved in coordinating the immune response. A defect in the IL-2 receptor gamma chain is one of the underlying causes of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). This particular defect typically follows an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance. SCID is characterized by severe, recurrent infections (e.g., bacterial diarrhea, oral candidiasis, respiratory tract infections) and failure to thrive. Patients can also develop a diffuse, eczematous rash. Patients with this condition often have absent thymic shadow on chest x-ray because of impaired development of the thymus gland. Peripheral lymphoid organs, such as lymph nodes and tonsils, may also be absent. In most US states, children are screened for SCID at birth using PCR amplification of T-cell receptor excision circles (TRECs).

Adenosine deaminase deficiency, which follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, can also cause SCID.
questions.hint: The presence of failure to thrive and recurrent infections caused by bacteria (e.g., pneumonia), fungi (e.g., oral thrush), and viruses in this infant indicates impaired humoral and cell-mediated immunity, likely resulting from severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

questions.text: One week after starting amoxicillin for sinusitis, a 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with fever, rash, and myalgia. She has been hospitalized multiple times for recurrent streptococcal pneumonia and meningitis. She appears tired. Examination shows a diffuse urticarial rash. Her antibiotic is discontinued. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for her recurrent infections?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired leukocyte adhesion is seen in leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1, which may present with recurrent infections during childhood. However, affected children would have a history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord stump, omphalitis, and/or impaired wound healing instead of recurrent streptococcal infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Defective formation of the membrane attack complex occurs in terminal complement deficiency, which puts affected individuals at increased risk for Neisseria infections (e.g., Meningococcal meningitis). There is no increased susceptibility to streptococcal infections as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Defective superoxide production by neutrophils and macrophages is seen in chronic granulomatous disease due to a defect in NADPH oxidase. While this condition is also characterized by recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, infection with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus) is more common, rather than the catalase-negative (e.g., Streptococcus) infections seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Complement factor C3 is a precursor for C3b, which plays a major role in opsonization of pathogens and immune complexes. C3 deficiency results in increased susceptibility to infections by encapsulated bacteria, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis. Patients with C3 deficiency classically present with recurring severe upper respiratory infections (e.g., sinusitis), pneumonia, and meningitis, as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with selective IgA deficiency are usually asymptomatic but may present with recurrent airway infections (IgA plays an important role in mucosal immunity) and anaphylactic reactions. Although this patient has recurrent upper respiratory infections and current hypersensitivity reaction, her history of recurrent streptococcal meningitis suggests impaired complement-mediated immunity. Moreover, other manifestations of selective IgA deficiency such as atopy and a history of GI infections are missing in this patient.
questions.hint: This girl's history of recurrent streptococcal infections and current hypersensitivity reaction is concerning for C3 deficiency.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of recurrent infections and easy bruising. He has been hospitalized 3 times for severe skin and respiratory infections, which responded to treatment with antibiotics. Examination shows sparse silvery hair. The skin is hypopigmented and there are diffuse petechiae. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 8 g/dL, leukocyte count of 3000/mm3, and platelet count of 45,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD1) is caused by an autosomal recessive defect in CD18, a subunit of beta-2 integrin, which results in an inability of leukocytes to migrate to the site of infection. Patients manifest shortly after birth with recurrent, nonpurulent infections, poor wound healing, omphalitis (classically with delayed umbilical cord stump separation), and severe periodontitis/gingivitis. Neutrophilia, not neutropenia, is also characteristic. During active infection, marked leukocytosis is present, as white blood cells are recruited into circulation and cannot extravasate. While skin and mucosal infections are common features of LAD1, hypopigmentation and diffuse petechiae are not, nor is pancytopenia or a blood smear finding of giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets.

B) INCORRECT:

A defective CD40 ligand causes hyper-IgM syndrome type 1 (HIGM1), a disorder characterized by impaired class-switch recombination that manifests in infancy with recurrent infections with encapsulated bacteria and opportunistic infections. Common features of this disorder also include chronic diarrhea from Cryptosporidium infection and failure to thrive. Sinopulmonary infections are a common manifestation of HIGM1, but recurrent skin infections, partial albinism, diffuse petechiae, pancytopenia, and a blood smear finding of giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets are not.

C) INCORRECT:

A defect in the Bruton tyrosine kinase gene (BTK) is responsible for X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), a primary humoral immunodeficiency characterized by susceptibility to infection with encapsulated bacteria and certain viruses (especially enteroviruses). XLA typically first manifests at 3–6 months of age with recurrent respiratory infections and otitis media because infants generally retain passively acquired maternal antibodies up until this point. Recurrent skin infections, partial albinism, and pancytopenia are not features of BTK, nor is the blood smear finding of giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

D) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the WAS gene is the underlying cause of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which can manifest in infancy with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura and recurrent infections, especially with encapsulated bacteria and opportunistic pathogens. Severe eczema, which is not present in this patient, is a characteristic finding of the disorder. Partial albinism, coagulation defects, and giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets are not seen in WAS, nor is pancytopenia or a blood smear finding of giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets.

E) INCORRECT:

A defect in the interleukin-2 receptor subunit gamma gene (IL2RG) is the most common mutation associated with severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID), which manifests soon after birth with sepsis, recurrent episodes of otitis media, chronic diarrhea, and mucocutaneous candidiasis. Laboratory studies would show absent T cells rather than pancytopenia. Partial albinism, coagulation defects, and giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets are not seen in SCID.

F) INCORRECT:

Defective NADPH oxidase results in chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which typically manifests in infancy with recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus, Aspergillus spp., Burkholderia cepacia, and Serratia marcescens. Common features of CGD include lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive, none of which are seen in this patient. Partial albinism, coagulation defects, pancytopenia, and giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets are not seen in CGD.

G) CORRECT:

A defective lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST) is the underlying pathophysiology of Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS). It causes a fusion defect in granules of all cells, resulting in giant intracellular granules. In addition, a microtubule polymerization dysfunction impairs the fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, which affects the normal immune response of neutrophils and monocytes. CHS patients who survive up to adolescence or longer (∼ 10%) develop severe defects of the peripheral and central nervous system (e.g., neuropathies, intellectual decline, dementia, ataxia).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Inclusion bodies (examples indicated by arrows) and polymorphous nuclei (green overlay) can be seen within the leukocytes.

These findings are consistent with Chediak-Higashi syndrome.
questions.hint: The infant's blood smear shows giant granules in granulocytes and platelets, a characteristic finding of Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS). This condition is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder characterized by recurrent pyogenic infections (involving the skin, respiratory tract, and mucous membranes), partial albinism with various degrees of skin hypopigmentation and silvery-white hair, pancytopenia, and mild coagulation defects that result in easy bruising and mucosal bleeding in early childhood.

questions.text: A 3086-g (6-lb) male newborn is delivered at 39 weeks' gestation to a 29-year-old woman. Initial examination shows micrognathia, a broad nasal bridge, short philtrum, and a cleft palate. Intermittent muscle spasms are seen predominantly in the hands and feet. A harsh systolic murmur is heard over the lower left sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this infant’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A microdeletion in the elastin gene on chromosome 7 causes Williams syndrome, which can present with a broad nasal bridge, micrognathia, a systolic murmur due to supravalvular aortic stenosis, and normal birth weight, as seen here. However, the murmur of aortic stenosis would be best heard at the right upper sternal border (aortic area), and patients with William syndrome would have a long rather than short philtrum, an elfin-like facies, and hypercalcemia rather than carpopedal spasm, which is a feature of hypocalcemia.
Image Description:

Photograph of a child with a broad forehead, midfacial hypoplasia, a short nose (with a flat nasal bridge), an everted lower lip, full cheeks and lips and low-set ears.

This appearance is often described as “elfin” facies and commonly seen in Williams syndrome, although definitive diagnosis would require genetic testing.

B) CORRECT:

Microdeletions in the long arm of chromosome 22 cause congenital heart defects (e.g., VSD, conotruncal abnormalities), craniofacial abnormalities (velocardiofacial syndrome), and/or aberrant development of the thymus and parathyroid glands, which are derived from the 3rd and 4th branchial pouches (DiGeorge syndrome). Hypocalcemia caused by parathyroid aplasia (primary hypoparathyroidism) would explain the carpopedal spasms in this neonate. Thymic aplasia would result in T-cell deficiency and increased risk of infections by opportunistic pathogens. Newborns with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome can have a normal birth weight but will eventually develop failure to thrive due to recurrent infections and/or heart failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21 causes Down syndrome (trisomy 21), which is the most common type of trisomy. Down syndrome can manifest with a broad nasal bridge, congenital heart defects (e.g., VSD), and a normal birth weight, as seen here. However, hypotonia rather than tetany is expected, and this patient does not present with other characteristic features of Down syndrome, such as a smooth philtrum, upward slanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, and simian palmar crease.
Image Description:

Upward slanting of the eyelids, prominent epicanthal folds (resulting in almond-shaped eyes), broad and flat nasal bridge, prominent tongue due to macroglossia and muscular hypotonia, low-set ears, and a short neck.

D) INCORRECT:

Meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 13 causes Patau syndrome (trisomy 13), which can present with a broad nasal bridge, cleft palate, micrognathia, and congenital heart defects (e.g., VSD), as seen here. However, tetany would not be expected, and other features characteristic of Patau syndrome, such as low birth weight (due to IUGR), holoprosencephaly or microcephaly, microphthalmia, postaxial polydactyly, and cutis aplasia, are not present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p) cause cri-du-chat syndrome. Affected neonates can have a broad nasal bridge, short philtrum, micrognathia, and congenital heart defects (e.g., VSD), as seen here. However, hypotonia rather than tetany would be expected, and other characteristic features of cri-du-chat syndrome, such as a high-pitched, cat-like cry and low birth weight (due to IUGR), are not present in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 18 causes Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), which can result in micrognathia, cleft palate, congenital heart defects (e.g., VSD), and clenched fists with overlapping digits (which may be mistaken for carpal spasms). However, other characteristic features of Edward syndrome, such as low birth weight (due to IUGR), low-set ears, prominent occiput, rocker bottom feet, are not present in this patient.
questions.hint: A chest x-ray would likely show an absent thymic shadow.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent skin lesions. The lesions first appeared at the age of 3 months. He has also had several episodes of respiratory tract infections, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent fevers since birth. The boy attends daycare. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for height and 10th percentile for weight. He appears ill. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Examination shows several raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groin, and extremities; some are purulent. Bilateral cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy are present. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Impaired repair of double-strand DNA breaks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defective microtubule polymerization is seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS). Although patients with CHS may also present with recurrent (usually pyogenic) infections, features of CHS such as bleeding abnormalities, albinism, and neurologic dysfunction are missing in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

The NADPH oxidase enzyme is responsible for the respiratory burst (oxidative burst) within phagolysosomes, a component of phagocytic cells, which causes a rapid release of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that can destroy bacteria. In patients with defective NADPH oxidase, also known as chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), this reaction does not occur. This leads to impaired function of phagocytic cells and makes patients susceptible to infection, as in this patient, usually with catalase-positive organisms. The nitroblue tetrazolium test and the dihydrorhodamine flow cytometry test are used to check for NADPH oxidase activity and to diagnose chronic granulomatous disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired repair of double-strand DNA breaks is seen in ataxia-telangiectasia. Although patients with ataxia-telangiectasia can also present with recurrent infections, features such as progressive ataxia, telangiectasias, and malignancies (e.g., leukemia, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, gastric carcinoma) are not present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A defect in Bruton tyrosine kinase, which is expressed in the cytoplasm of B cells, is seen in Bruton agammaglobulinemia (XLA). Although patients with XLA present with recurrent, severe pyogenic infections (e.g., pneumonia, otitis media), this patient does not show hypoplasia of the tonsils and other lymphoid tissues (due to very low levels of B cells). In addition, skin infections are not common in XLA, and this patient has had respiratory tract infections and recurrent fever since birth. Infections in XLA typically occur from 6 months onwards, when passive immunity from transplacental maternal IgG expires.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired actin cytoskeleton reorganization is seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). Although patients with WAS may also present with recurrent infections (e.g., otitis media) and skin lesions, this patient's dermatologic abnormalities are not consistent with purpura or eczema, which would not be purulent. Remember the mnemonic for WAS: WIPE (Wiskott-Aldrich, Infections, Purpura, Eczema).
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurring respiratory infections, lymphadenopathy, and inflammatory, pustular lesions, starting at a very young age. Together, these features suggest impaired functioning of phagocytic cells, making him especially susceptible to infection with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., S. aureus, E. coli, Aspergillus).

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the physician for follow-up examination 1 week after admission to the hospital for bacterial pneumonia. She has had multiple episodes of purulent otitis media and infectious diarrhea since the age of 6 months. She underwent treatment for oral thrush 1 month ago. There is no family history of serious illness. Her height and weight are both below the 10th percentile. Physical examination shows no visible tonsils and slightly decreased breath sounds in the left lower lobe. Laboratory studies show increased deoxyadenosine concentration in both the serum and urine. An x-ray of the chest shows an absent thymic shadow. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased levels of circulating parathyroid hormone in association with immunodeficiency can be seen in patients with DiGeorge syndrome. This syndrome also manifests with thymic hypoplasia and, possibly, the absence of tonsils. However, other features of CATCH-22 (e.g., congenital heart disease, dysmorphic facial features, hypocalcemia) would also be expected. Increased deoxyadenosine concentration in both the serum and urine and absent tonsils are not associated with DiGeorge syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased circulating IgE levels can be seen in patients with Job syndrome, which is an immunodeficiency characterized by impaired neutrophil recruitment to the site of infection. Further manifestations would typically include coarse facial features, eosinophilia, severe eczema, and recurrent abscess formation. Increased deoxyadenosine concentration in both the serum and urine, absent tonsils, and an absent thymus shadow on x-ray are not associated with Job syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Circulating B cells are decreased (not increased) in SCID due to adenosine deaminase deficiency and in X-linked agammaglobulinemia, an immunodeficiency characterized by a defective Bruton tyrosine kinase gene. Although X-linked agammaglobulinemia can also present with recurrent, severe pyogenic infections beginning > 4–6 months after birth, it is extremely rare in girls given its mode of inheritance. Absent thymic shadow, tonsillar hypoplasia, and elevated deoxyadenosine levels are also not consistent with this diagnosis. In X-linked SCID (the most common variant), the number of circulating B cells is normal.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is most likely due to an autosomal recessive adenosine deaminase deficiency (the second most common cause of SCID), which results in disrupted purine metabolism and accumulation of metabolites (including deoxyadenosine and dATP) that are toxic to maturing lymphocytes. Accumulation of dATP also inhibits the function of ribonucleotide reductase, which is essential for the generation of deoxynucleotides, thereby impairing the proliferation of lymphocytes. These effects on lymphocytes proliferation and maturation lead to a decreased number of circulating T cells, B cells, and NK cells, resulting in both cellular and humoral immunodeficiency. Clinically, patients with SCID have no tonsils, no palpable lymph nodes, and a rudimentary thymus.

In contrast, X-linked SCID (the most common variant) is caused by a defect in the IL-2 receptor, which is required for T-cell proliferation. Thus, X-linked SCID manifests with a decrease in circulating T cells and a normal number of B cells.

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombocytopenia would be consistent with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, which is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency characterized by eczema, purpura, and recurrent opportunistic infections beginning at birth. The condition is primarily seen in males. Increased deoxyadenosine concentration in both the serum and urine, absent tonsils, and an absent thymic shadow on x-ray are not associated with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

An increased number of circulating neutrophils can be seen in leukocyte-adhesion deficiency, which is characterized by a defect in leukocytic chemotaxis and typically presents with recurrent non-purulent bacterial infections and poor wound healing. This patient has a history of recurrent purulent infections, making this an unlikely diagnosis. Elevated deoxyadenosine levels, absent tonsils, and an absent thymus shadow on x-ray are also inconsistent with this diagnosis.

Although this patient could have peripheral neutrophilia due to her recent bacterial infection, this finding is not characteristic of her underlying immunodeficiency.
questions.hint: Recurrent infections (bacterial and fungal), failure to thrive, absent tonsils, and absent thymus shadow on x-ray suggest severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician because of throat pain for 2 days. She had frequent episodes of oral thrush as a baby and has been treated for vaginal yeast infection twice in the past year. Physical examination shows white patches on the tongue and palate. Scraping off the patches reveals erythematous oral mucosa with pinpoint bleeding. Leukocyte count is within normal range. Exposure to nitroblue tetrazolium turns the patient's neutrophils dark blue. A deficiency in which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's recurrent infections?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adenosine deaminase deficiency causes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Although this condition can manifest with recurrent fungal infections, patients are also susceptible to bacterial, viral, and protozoal infections and typically have failure to thrive. Without bone marrow transplant, SCID is usually fatal by 1 year of age.

B) INCORRECT:
