Pyruvate kinase deficiency impairs normal glycolysis, which reduces the availability of ATP (particularly in cells that are dependent on glycolysis for energy, such as red blood cells). This condition manifests in infancy with hemolytic anemia but does not increase the risk of recurrent Candida infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency reduces the availability of glutathione and increases the susceptibility of red blood cells to oxidative stress, which can lead to hemolytic anemia. This condition does not increase the risk of recurrent Candida infections.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

D) INCORRECT:

NADPH oxidase deficiency causes chronic granulomatous disease, which manifests with recurrent infections by catalase-positive organisms. Though infection with Candida is also possible, other organisms (e.g., Aspergillus, S. aureus) are more common. Moreover, patients with this deficiency have a negative nitroblue tetrazolium test (dye fails to turn blue).

E) CORRECT:

Patients with myeloperoxidase deficiency are typically asymptomatic but can also develop recurrent Candida infections (e.g., oral thrush and vulvovaginal candidiasis) due to ineffective hypochlorous acid production during the oxidative burst. The nitroblue tetrazolium test is positive (normal) in these patients because NADPH oxidase function is intact and still able to reduce the dye to blue. The diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing or immunohistochemical staining.
questions.hint: This girl has had multiple Candida infections but no history of frequent bacterial or viral infections. A normal nitroblue tetrazolium test shows intact ability to reduce the yellow dye to a dark blue formazan.

questions.text:
A 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a rash on her face that first appeared 3 days ago. She was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She is at the 25th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows small perioral vesicles surrounded by erythema and honey-colored crusts. Laboratory studies show:



At birth
Day 30



Hemoglobin
18.0 g/dL
15.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7,600/mm3

6,830/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
2%
3%


Eosinophils
13%
10%


Lymphocytes
60%
63%


Monocytes
25%
24%


Platelet count
220,000/mm3

223,000/mm3




Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Infants with severe congenital neutropenia are prone to develop recurrent bacterial infections, including otitis media, respiratory infections, or oral and skin infections secondary to staphylococcal and streptococcal pathogens (such as impetigo). Laboratory findings reveal absolute neutropenia (often as low as < 200/μL) and relative monocytosis, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

B) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which presents initially with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, coryza, and headache. These symptoms are followed by a malar rash on the cheek with circumoral pallor (slapped-cheek appearance) and spread of exanthem to the extremities and trunk, unlike the honey-crusted lesion on this patient's face. Moreover, parvovirus B19 infection has been associated with transient normocytic anemia and a low reticulocyte count that mainly occurs in immunocompromised patients or those with a chronic hemolytic disease, which does not fit with this patient's isolated neutropenia.
Image Description:

The cheeks are bright red (slapped-cheek rash) and a diffuse, red, confluent rash with macules and papules is visible over the body of this infant.

This is the characteristic cutaneous appearance of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

C) INCORRECT:

Although children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia are susceptible to infections, they usually manifest with pallor, easy bruising, or hepatosplenomegaly. Patients also typically have anemia and thrombocytopenia with normal or elevated WBC count and lymphoblasts on peripheral smear. This patient, however, has isolated neutropenia and a normal absolute lymphocyte count.

D) INCORRECT:

Most individuals with selective IgA deficiency are asymptomatic, but some patients can develop recurrent sinopulmonary and Giardia lamblia infections, which are not seen in this patient. Also, an association with autoimmune disorders such as gluten-sensitive enteropathy has been observed, which are not reported here either. Moreover, serum studies would show isolated IgA deficiency without affecting the white blood cell count, unlike what is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Diamond-Blackfan syndrome would manifest with normochromic macrocytic anemia, low reticulocyte count, and normal WBC count, and not the neutropenia seen in this patient. Additionally, in 50% of cases, it is associated with other congenital malformations, such as craniofacial abnormalities, short stature, triphalangeal thumbs, and VSD, none of which are observed in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

While individuals with leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 are susceptible to recurrent bacterial infections that may affect the skin, as seen in this patient, they also have delayed umbilical cord separation, impaired wound healing and absent pus formation, all of which are absent. Moreover, one would expect a massive increase in absolute neutrophil count (30,000–100,000/μL) instead of isolated neutropenia.
questions.hint: This patient's honey-colored crusted skin rash is typical of impetigo, which can be caused by the catalase-positive bacteria Staphylococcus aureus. Patients with decreased or defective granulocyte function are susceptible to bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of fever, cough, and ear pain over the past 2 days. He has had recurrent respiratory tract infections and several episodes of giardiasis and viral gastroenteritis since he was 6 months of age. Examination shows decreased breath sounds over both lung fields and bilateral purulent otorrhea. His palatine tonsils and adenoids are hypoplastic. Quantitative flow cytometry of his blood shows decreased levels of cells that express CD19, CD20, and CD21. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Microdeletion on the long arm of chromosome 22

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the WAS gene causes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). WAS can cause recurrent infections, as seen in this patient, but it typically also causes eczema and thrombocytopenic purpura. The absence of these findings, along with this patient's hypoplastic lymphoid tissue and low levels of mature B cells, which are not typically seen in WAS, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A defect in the IL-2R gamma chain is the most common cause of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Children with SCID appear normal at birth but progressively develop recurrent, severe infections (including bacterial, fungal, viral, and protozoal infections), and fail to thrive. SCID typically causes more severe infections than those seen in this patient, and it is usually lethal within the first year of life if not diagnosed and treated immediately. Diagnostic criteria for SCID include decreased T-cell receptor excision circles and absent T cells on peripheral blood flow cytometry, but a deficiency of mature B cells would not be expected.

C) CORRECT:

A mutation in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA). BTK is a signal transduction molecule found on B cells. Without BTK, proper B-cell maturation cannot occur, which causes a severe reduction in plasma cells and immunoglobulins (panhypogammaglobulinemia). Although recurrent infections are a feature of many immunodeficiency disorders, tonsillar hypoplasia (due to low B-cell volume), as seen in this patient, is especially suggestive of XLA.

The diagnosis of XLA is confirmed by flow cytometry that shows reduced levels of B cells (marked by CD19, CD20, and CD21) and normal levels of T cells. Treatment for XLA consists of IVIG and prophylactic antibiotics.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

D) INCORRECT:

A microdeletion on the long arm of chromosome 22 causes DiGeorge syndrome, in which the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches fail to develop. Patients with DiGeorge syndrome may present with recurrent infections, which are also seen in this patient. However, in patients with DiGeorge syndrome, these infections are the result of a hypoplastic thymus and the subsequent T-cell deficiency, rather than due to low levels of mature B cells. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical features of DiGeorge syndrome, such as hypocalcemia (due to hypoparathyroidism), cleft palate, facial abnormalities, and cardiac anomalies.

E) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the NADPH oxidase gene can lead to defective NADPH oxidase enzyme, which causes chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). CGD can manifest with recurrent infections, as seen in this patient. In addition, patients with CGD often present with skin conditions (e.g., recurrent skin infections, eczematous rash) and symptoms typical of granuloma formation in the gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts (e.g., dysphagia, abdominal pain, dysuria, urinary retention). However, these symptoms are not present in this patient. Finally, CGD would not explain the low levels of mature B cells.

F) INCORRECT:

A defect in the beta-2 integrin (CD18) causes leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD-1). Although LAD causes recurrent infections, these tend to be nonsuppurative skin and soft tissue infections caused by the inability of neutrophils to extravasate from the circulation to the infection. However, these types of infection are not seen in this patient. In addition, this patient does not present with other typical features of LAD, such as poor wound healing and a history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord. Finally, LAD would not explain the low levels of mature B cells.

G) INCORRECT:

A deficiency in the IL-17 receptor is associated with chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis (CMC). Unlike patients with CMC, this patient does not have a history of recurrent noninvasive Candida albicans infections of the skin, mucous membranes, and/or nails. In addition, CMC would not explain the low levels of mature B cells.
questions.hint: Low levels of mature B cells (which express CD19, CD20, and CD21) in addition to recurrent episodes of respiratory and gastrointestinal tract infections when a child is older than 6 months (when the maternal IgG has decreased) are highly suggestive of X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of intermittent abdominal cramps and recurrent episodes of foul-smelling greasy diarrhea for 3 months. He has a history of recurrent upper respiratory infection. The abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation and resonant to percussion. A photomicrograph of a stool sample is shown. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with IgA deficiency may develop anti-IgA antibodies. Any transfusion that contains even trace amounts of IgA (e.g., RBC transfusions) can cause an anaphylactic transfusion reaction in such patients. If transfusions are necessary, the patient should first be screened for anti-IgA antibodies and transfusion should be prepared from another IgA-deficient individual. If this is not possible and the patient does have documented anti-IgA antibodies, saline-washed RBC transfusions can be used.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastric adenocarcinoma is a potential complication of common variable immunodeficiency (presumably due to alterations of p53 and Helicobacter pylori infection). As with most immunodeficiencies, CVID causes recurrent infection, including pyogenic upper respiratory infections and chronic diarrhea. However, CVID is usually diagnosed at 20–35 years of age, and it would be highly unlikely to manifest in a 5-year-old child. While CVID cannot be entirely excluded in this patient, his age makes another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Progressive peripheral neuropathy is characteristic of Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which most commonly manifests with severe recurrent pyogenic infections of the skin, mucous membranes, and respiratory tract (caused by S. pyogenes, S. aureus, or Pseudomonas spp). In addition, children with Chediak-Higashi syndrome typically also have partial albinism, splenomegaly, pancytopenia, and mild coagulopathy. There is no evidence that this patient has any of these features.

D) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous granulomas are characteristic of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which manifests with recurrent, severe infections of the lungs, skin, bone, and lymph nodes by catalase-positive organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus). Chronic diarrhea due to giardiasis is not typical in this condition. Furthermore, other characteristic features of CGD, like anemia, lymphadenopathy, and severe skin infections, are also absent here.

E) INCORRECT:

Disseminated tuberculosis is especially common in patients with a deficiency of interleukin-12 receptor. Disease onset occurs on average at 1–3 years of age. Patients with IL-12 receptor deficiency typically present with mycobacterial infections and salmonellosis as well as mucocutaneous candidiasis. This patient, however, presents with recurrent upper respiratory infections and giardiasis.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows an egg-shaped cell with a two-layered cell wall, multiple nuclei, and longitudinal threadlike-structures called median bodies. These are the typical characteristics of Giardia lamblia cysts. Recurrent sinopulmonary (mostly caused by encapsulated bacteria) and gastrointestinal infections (e.g., giardiasis) are typical in selective IgA deficiency, as secretory IgA antibodies are a crucial part of mucosal defense.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, poor feeding, and cough that began after she returned with her family from a trip to Mexico 1 week ago. Her temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 78/56 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest shows a reticulonodular infiltrate throughout the lungs and a left-sided pleural effusion. A peripheral blood smear shows acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Low serum IgG, IgA, and IgM levels
Mutations in common gamma chain gene
Absent B cells with normal T-cell count

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the WAS gene is the cause of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which is characterized by impaired T-cell function and thrombocytopenia. Affected children often present with a triad of eczema, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), and recurrent opportunistic infections within the first years of life. Although the infection seen in this child could occur in WAS, the absence of previous infections, TTP, and eczema make WAS an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Low serum IgG, IgA, and IgM levels are detected in individuals with common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), which only affects B cells. The disorder manifests with recurrent pyogenic respiratory infections and is associated with an increased risk for lymphoma, gastric cancer, and autoimmune disorders (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis). Unlike many other congenital immunodeficiency disorders, CVID has an age of onset of 20–35 years and does not manifest in children.

C) INCORRECT:

Isolated low serum IgA levels are suggestive of selective IgA deficiency, the most common primary immunodeficiency. Although recurrent respiratory infections, sinusitis, or chronic diarrhea may occur, many affected individuals are asymptomatic or have a protracted but mild disease course. This child's previously unremarkable medical history and sudden onset of severe disease cannot be explained by selective IgA deficiency and is indicative of a much more severe immunodeficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutations in common gamma chain gene are the cause of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), which results in a severe reduction of both the number and functionality of T cells and B cells. Affected infants appear healthy at birth but present with severe, recurrent infections and failure to thrive a few months later. Common infections include bacterial diarrhea, chronic candidiasis, as well as viral and protozoal infections. These features are not seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased parathyroid hormone levels together with low Ca2+ levels and a reduced absolute T-lymphocyte count are diagnostic of DiGeorge syndrome. Affected patients present with a specific set of symptoms (CATCH-22), which are absent in this patient. As a result of thymic aplasia, patients with DiGeorge syndrome have an increased susceptibility to viral or fungal infections but not bacterial infections.
Image Description:

Broad nasal bridge and nasal tip, ocular hypertelorism, dysplastic and low-set ears as well as micrognathia.

F) INCORRECT:

Absent B cells with a normal T-cell count are detected in individuals with X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA; i.e., Bruton-agammaglobulinemia), an X-linked recessive disorder that exclusively affects boys and causes a complete deficiency of B lymphocytes, which cannot be the case in this female patient. In addition, patients with XLA usually have a history of recurring, often pyogenic infections (e.g., otitis media, pneumonia) starting after 6 months of age, which is when transplacental IgG-mediated passive immunity subsides.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

G) CORRECT:

Decreased IFN-γ levels are a diagnostic feature of IL-12 receptor deficiency, a congenital T-cell immunodeficiency. Normally, antigen-presenting macrophages release IL-12, which triggers T-helper cells to transform to T1 type. T1-helper cells then release IFN-γ to activate macrophages. If IL-12 receptors on naive T cells are defective, T-helper cells will not transform to T1-helper cells and will not release IFN-γ; the lack of IFN-γ results in decreased macrophage activation. If macrophages are not activated, they will not trigger cytotoxicity in cells infected with intracellular pathogens such as mycobacteria and salmonella. Patients with IL-12 receptor deficiency often present with features of disseminated disease (such as miliary tuberculosis), sepsis, and DIC.

Treatment for IL-12 receptor deficiency consists of antibiotics and supplementation of IFN-γ.
questions.hint: This previously healthy child presents with signs and symptoms of miliary tuberculosis (e.g., cough, miliary pattern on x-ray, recent travel to endemic area, acid-fast bacilli on blood smear); this strongly suggests IL-12 receptor deficiency.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of intermittent watery diarrhea for several months. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. He was diagnosed with eczematous dermatitis at 3 months old. His height and weight are below the 5th percentile. Immunologic evaluation shows a defect in activated regulatory T cells. A genetic analysis shows a mutation in the FOXP3 gene. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypoplasia of the tonsils is a finding in Bruton agammaglobulinemia, which is caused by a mutation in the B-cell tyrosine kinase gene. Patients with Bruton agammaglobulinemia typically present with recurrent bacterial infections after 3–6 months of age (when transplacentally transferred maternal IgG is no longer active). FOXP3 gene mutations are not involved in the pathogenesis of Bruton agammaglobulinemia. Conversely, patients with IPEX syndrome typically have lymphoid hyperplasia, which causes enlarged tonsils.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

B) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhagic diathesis is a feature of Wiskott‑Aldrich syndrome, a congenital immunodeficiency that is caused by a mutation in the WAS gene. The disease also manifests with recurrent infections (especially sinopulmonary infections or those caused by opportunistic pathogens) and eczematous dermatitis. Although this patient has skin findings consistent with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, a FOXP3 gene mutation is not involved in the pathogenesis of this condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Ocular telangiectasias can be seen in ataxia telangiectasia, which is caused by a mutation in the ATM gene. Patients with ataxia telangiectasia typically present with telangiectasias on the face and conjunctivae, progressive cerebellar ataxia, athetosis, and recurrent infections (due to a T-cell defect). This patient's dermatologic findings are inconsistent with this diagnosis. Also, FOXP3 gene mutations are not involved in the pathogenesis of this condition.

D) CORRECT:

Autoimmune endocrinopathy is a feature of immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked syndrome (IPEX syndrome), which is caused by a mutation in the FOXP3 gene. FOXP3 encodes a transcription factor required for the normal development of regulatory T cells; impaired functionality of the FOXP3 protein leads to a loss of tolerance to self-antigens. Patients with IPEX syndrome typically present in the first 6 months of life with enteropathy, skin conditions (e.g., eczema, erythroderma, psoriasis), type 1 diabetes mellitus (the most common endocrine disorder in IPEX syndrome), and autoimmune thyroid disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Retained primary teeth are a feature of Job syndrome, a congenital immunodeficiency caused by a mutation in the STAT3 gene that impairs neutrophil chemotaxis. Patients classically present with coarse facies, abscesses (recurrent bacterial infections), retained primary teeth, elevated serum IgE, and dermatologic pathology (e.g., eczema). A FOXP3 gene mutation is not involved in the pathogenesis of Job syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

Anaphylaxis to blood transfusions can be seen in selective IgA deficiency. The absence of host IgA causes the development of anti-IgA antibodies, which target foreign IgA molecules in donor blood and lead to an anaphylactic response. This condition can be diagnosed by an absent or near-absent serum IgA level with normal IgG and IgM levels. Patients with selective IgA deficiency are often asymptomatic but some may present with recurrent sinusitis or respiratory infections. FOXP3 gene mutations are not involved in the pathogenesis of selective IgA deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's findings of enteropathy, eczema, failure to thrive, and a mutation in the FOXP3 gene are diagnostic of IPEX syndrome.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is evaluated as a potential kidney donor for his father. His medical history is significant only for mild recurrent infections as a child. He subsequently undergoes a donor nephrectomy that is complicated by unexpected blood loss. During resuscitation, he is transfused with 4 units of O negative packed red blood cells. Shortly after the transfusion begins, he develops generalized pruritus. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 80/64 mm Hg. Physical examination shows expiratory wheezing in all lung fields and multiple pink, edematous wheals over the trunk and neck. His hemoglobin concentration is 8 g/dL. Serum studies show a haptoglobin concentration of 78 mg/dL (N = 30–200) and lactate dehydrogenase level of 80 U/L. This patient's underlying condition is most likely due to which of the following?

choices.text: Absence of neutrophilic reactive oxygen species
Absence of mature circulating B cells
Impaired development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Impaired production of secretory immunoglobulins is the underlying pathology of IgA deficiency. The patient's history of recurrent infections as a child and the development of a nonhemolytic response to transfused blood indicate this condition. An IgA deficient host will develop anti-IgA antibodies (usually IgG but occasionally IgE). When exposed to products containing IgA, such as ordinary packed red cells, the recipient's preformed anti-IgA antibodies can cause a type I hypersensitivity response (anaphylaxis).

B) INCORRECT:

Defective IL-2R gamma chain is the underlying genetic mutation in many cases of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Individuals with SCID are often asymptomatic at birth but survival to adulthood is extremely unlikely without bone marrow transplantation. Without this treatment, severe, recurrent infections occur and most often lead to death in infancy. Although this adult patient's history of recurrent infection suggests a congenital immunodeficiency, SCID is very unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

The absence of neutrophilic reactive oxygen species is the hallmark of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). In CGD, deficient NADPH oxidase causes the absence of reactive oxygen species and the subsequent oxidative burst that phagocytic cells rely on to kill microbes. Classically, individuals with CGD are susceptible to infections with catalase-positive organisms. Although this patient has a history of recurrent infections during childhood, CGD would not account for an anaphylactic response to blood transfusions.

D) INCORRECT:

Dysfunction of phagosome-lysosome fusion, which impairs neutrophil function, is the underlying pathology of Chediak-Higashi syndrome. This syndrome manifests with recurrent pyogenic infections. Although this patient has a history of recurrent infections during childhood, he does not have the typical features of Chediak-Higashi syndrome, e.g., albinism, photosensitivity, bleeding tendency, and peripheral neuropathy. Furthermore, the occurrence of an anaphylactic reaction to blood transfusion is not explained by Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

The absence of mature circulating B cells is the pathophysiologic mechanism of X-linked agammaglobulinemia. Infants with X-linked agammaglobulinemia are initially asymptomatic because of maternal IgG in their serum, but these molecules are no longer present by the age of 6 months. At this age, the first onset of severe, recurring infections is commonly seen. Without lifelong administration of gamma globulins and prophylactic antibiotics, the condition is most often lethal in childhood. This patient has a history of mild infections in childhood that have not required lifelong treatment, which is inconsistent with X-linked agammaglobulinemia. Furthermore, this condition would not explain the anaphylactic response to transfused blood products.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

F) INCORRECT:

Impaired development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches is the underlying cause of DiGeorge syndrome, which causes aplasia or hypoplasia of the thymus. Impaired development of the thymus causes a deficiency of T cells that manifests as recurrent, often severe infections with bacterial and fungal species. Other common features of DiGeorge syndrome include congenital heart defects and craniofacial abnormalities. The absence of these associated findings, along with this patient's history of limited infections, makes DiGeorge syndrome unlikely. Moreover, an anaphylactic reaction associated with blood transfusion is not expected in DiGeorge syndrome.
questions.hint: The development of urticaria, wheezing, tachycardia, and hypotension after receiving blood products suggests an anaphylactic transfusion reaction. The normal haptoglobin and lactate dehydrogenase values indicate that this is a nonhemolytic transfusion reaction.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for difficulty breathing and bluish discoloration of the lips for the past hour. During the past 3 months, the patient has had several upper respiratory tract infections and poor weight gain. Physical examination shows crackles over both lung fields and enlargement of the tonsils and cervical lymph nodes. His serum IgA, IgE, and IgG titers are decreased. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Methenamine silver staining of bronchial lavage fluid shows disc-shaped cysts. A defect in which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Actin filament assembly in leukocytes and platelets is impeded by a mutation in the WAS gene, which results in a defect in antigen presentation. WAS gene mutation is the cause of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency that manifests in early infancy with recurrent sinopulmonary infections (e.g., Pneumocystis pneumonia) and failure to thrive. However, affected patients usually also have bleeding manifestations, eczematous skin lesions, and increased rather than decreased IgA titers.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired neutrophil superoxide production is caused by a defect in NADPH oxidase and is seen in chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). CGD, which is a predominantly X-linked recessive condition, manifests during infancy with recurrent sinopulmonary infections. However, pneumonia caused by catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus, Serratia, Klebsiella, and Aspergillus is far more common than Pneumocystis pneumonia. Additionally, CGD also manifests with gastrointestinal obstruction or urinary retention caused by granulomas, which this patient does not have.

C) CORRECT:

Type 1 hyper-IgM syndrome is an X-linked immunodeficiency caused by a defect in T-cell receptor signaling (most commonly from a defect in CD40 ligand) that renders T cells unable to activate immunoglobulin class switching in B cells. These B cells produce IgM but are unable to produce other immunoglobulins (i.e., IgA, IgG, or IgE). In patients with a CD40 ligand defect, T cells cannot upregulate to cells that express the CD40 molecule. These cells are prevented from presenting antigens to T cells, which results in a weakened antigen-specific T-cell response and cell-mediated immunity. Affected patients are therefore at a higher risk of infection with a yeast-like fungus such as Pneumocystis.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired thymic organogenesis resulting in thymic aplasia occurs in severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID) and DiGeorge syndrome. Both diseases manifest with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and failure to thrive. Patients with DiGeorge syndrome can present in early infancy with Pneumocystis pneumonia and profound central cyanosis due to conotruncal anomalies (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot and pulmonary atresia). However, they would also present with facial dysmorphism (e.g., micrognathia), a cleft palate, a murmur, seizures, and/or tetany (due to hypocalcemia caused by primary hypoparathyroidism). SCID typically manifests with much more severe infections, including bacterial diarrhea, chronic candidiasis, viral, and protozoal infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Defective microtubule polymerization and subsequent impaired phagosome-lysosome fusion in neutrophils and macrophages occur in Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS), which is caused by a mutation in the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST). CHS has an autosomal recessive inheritance and manifests with recurrent sinopulmonary infections similar to those seen in this patient. However, it would also manifest with oculocutaneous albinism and/or ocular motility disorders (e.g., strabismus and nystagmus). Furthermore, infections in CHS are mostly caused by pyogenic organisms such as S. aureus, not by Pneumocystis pneumonia.

F) INCORRECT:

Impaired B-cell maturation resulting in decreased production of all immunoglobulin classes can be caused by a mutation in the Bruton tyrosine kinase gene (BTK). A BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which commonly manifests with recurrent sinopulmonary infections (causative pathogens include S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and very rarely, Pneumocystis pneumonia). However, it is uncommon for patients with XLA to develop symptoms before the age of 6 months because infants generally retain passively acquired maternal antibodies until this age.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase
questions.hint: This patient's infection is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii (appearing on methenamine silver staining as disc-shaped cysts with central spores), which suggests a defect in cell-mediated immunity. Decreased levels of serum IgA, IgE, and IgG should raise concern for a condition caused by defective immunoglobulin class switching.

questions.text: A 12-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a 4-week history of fever, malaise, cough, and difficulty breathing. He has had recurrent episodes of gastroenteritis since birth. Cardiopulmonary examination shows subcostal retractions and crackles bilaterally. There is enlargement of the cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral consolidations. A sputum culture shows colonies of Burkholderia cepacia. A blood sample is obtained and after the addition of nitroblue tetrazolium to the sample, neutrophils remain colorless. A defect in which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defect in B cell maturation is characteristic of Bruton agammaglobulinemia (X-linked agammaglobulinemia). Affected individuals will present with decreased production of all immunoglobulin classes. While Bruton agammaglobulinemia may manifest with recurrent (usually pyogenic) infections, it will also manifest with hypoplastic tonsils/lymphoid tissue, which is not seen here. Furthermore, this condition would not explain the abnormal nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) results.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

B) INCORRECT:

A defect in microtubule polymerization is seen in individuals with Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS), which may also present with recurrent (usually pyogenic) infections. However, other features of CHS such as bleeding abnormalities, albinism, and ocular motility disorders (e.g., strabismus, nystagmus) are missing in this patient. Furthermore, this syndrome would not explain the abnormal nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) results.

C) INCORRECT:

A defect in the T cell CD40 ligand is seen in individuals with type 1 hyper-IgM syndrome. This defect in T cell signaling impairs class switching in B cells. Therefore, affected individuals are able to produce IgM, but they are unable to produce other immunoglobulins, such as IgA, IgG, or IgE. Individuals with hyper-IgM syndrome are at increased risk for recurrent infections (usually sinopulmonary infections caused by Pneumocystis or Histoplasma and gastroenteritis caused by Cryptosporidium). However, this syndrome would not explain the abnormal nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) results.

D) INCORRECT:

A defect in actin filament assembly is seen in individuals with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which classically manifests with recurrent infections during infancy. However, the classic symptoms of eczema and bleeding diathesis are absent in this patient. Furthermore, this condition would not explain the abnormal nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) results.

E) CORRECT:

A defect in the NADPH oxidase complex is seen in individuals with chronic granulomatous disease. This enzyme complex converts oxygen to superoxide radicals, which are vitally important for the neutrophilic respiratory burst. In healthy individuals, the addition of colorless nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) to a blood sample would cause the reduction of NBT to a deep blue compound through the action of superoxide radicals. A defect in NADPH oxidase leads to a deficiency of superoxide production by PMNs and macrophages. This deficiency significantly reduces the ability of PMNs and macrophages to kill microorganisms, thus leading to recurrent infections.

The nitroblue tetrazolium test used to be the gold standard to test phagocytic oxidase activity, but it has been widely replaced by the dihydrorhodamine flow cytometry test.
questions.hint: This patient's history of recurrent infections, lymphadenopathy, and bacterial pneumonia with a catalase-positive organism are highly suggestive of chronic granulomatous disease.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of a productive cough. He has been treated twice for pneumonia over the past year and his mother is concerned that he has developed pneumonia again. Four months ago, he was treated for several nonpurulent, noninflamed soft tissue abscesses on his neck and face. The patient also has had a pruritic rash on his face since infancy that did not resolve despite treatment with topical corticosteroids. His father has also had recurrent pulmonary infections; he died in a motor vehicle collision last year. The patient is at the 25th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Physical examination shows a prominent forehead and a wide nasal bridge. Examination of the skin shows a diffuse eczematous rash. Crackles are heard at the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Serum studies show normal complement concentration and decreased interferon-γ concentration. A peripheral blood smear shows no abnormalities. Flow cytometry shows a deficiency of T helper 17 (Th17) cells. Genetic analysis confirms an autosomal dominant mutation of the STAT3 gene. Measurement of serum immunoglobulin concentrations before the current episode of pneumonia would most likely have shown which of the following set of findings?

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Increased serum IgE levels with eosinophilia and otherwise normal immunoglobulin levels are suggestive of hyper-IgE syndrome (Job syndrome). Hyper-IgE syndrome is caused by a mutation in the STAT3 gene, which leads to Th17 cell deficiency and decreased interferon-γ production by helper T cells. The lack of interferon-γ results in impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, causing patients to present with cold abscesses and recurrent sinopulmonary infections (e.g., pneumonia). Affected individuals also develop eczema (resembling atopic dermatitis) within the first few weeks of life. Hyper-IgE syndrome leads to the development of coarse facial features (due to skin and soft tissue thickening), primary teeth retention, and orthopedic problems (e.g., bone demineralization, pathological fractures, scoliosis, hyperextensible joints) as patients grow older.

The treatment of this condition consists of supportive care (e.g., topical emollients and corticosteroids to treat eczema) and prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole to prevent recurrent infections. The use of recombinant interferon-γ, high-dose intravenous immunoglobulin, and/or omalizumab may be considered in some instances.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased IgA and IgE with normal or decreased IgG and IgM serum levels is suggestive of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which typically manifests in males and can cause recurrent sinopulmonary infections, eczema, and eosinophilia. However, microthrombocytopenia, a characteristic feature of WAS, is not present in this child. WAS is not associated with the cold abscesses or facial dysmorphism seen in this patient. Moreover, the underlying etiology of WAS is an X-linked recessive mutation in the WAS gene, not STAT3. This defect impairs actin reorganization within T cells and platelets; on flow cytometry, the counts of all T cell subsets would be normal or decreased (due to accelerated T cell death), unlike the isolated Th17 cell deficiency seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Isolated low serum IgA levels are suggestive of selective IgA deficiency (sIgAD), the most common primary immunodeficiency. Most individuals with sIgAD are asymptomatic or have a protracted yet mild disease course. Some patients with sIgAD may have eczema (due to atopy) and recurrent sinopulmonary and/or gastrointestinal tract infections, as seen here. However, cold abscesses, facial dysmorphism, and eosinophilia are not associated with sIgAD. Moreover, flow cytometry is usually normal in sIgAD.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased IgM levels with a deficiency of other immunoglobulin classes is seen in hyper IgM syndrome (HIGM), which typically manifests in male infants or toddlers with recurrent pyogenic sinopulmonary infections. However, the most common underlying etiology of HIGM is an X-linked recessive defect in the gene coding for the CD40 ligand; this defect impairs class switching in B cells but does not decrease immune cell counts on flow cytometry. Moreover, cold abscesses, facial dysmorphism, and eosinophilia are not consistent with HGIM.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased monoclonal IgG levels with a deficiency of other immunoglobulin classes can be seen in multiple myeloma (MM), which can cause recurrent infections. However, MM usually manifests in adulthood rather than in infancy, and it would not cause cold abscesses, facial dysmorphism, or eosinophilia. Instead, affected individuals develop hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and/or lytic bone lesions. In addition, flow cytometry in the case of advanced MM (i.e., bone marrow infiltration) would show a decrease in all types of leukocytes, not just in Th17 cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Globally low immunoglobulin levels are seen in common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), and severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), each of which can result in recurrent sinopulmonary infections. However, CVID manifests after the age of 2 years (typically at 20–35 years of age), whereas this child has had recurrent infections since the age of 1 year. Both XLA and SCID manifest during late infancy and primarily affect boys, but they are caused by different mutations (BTK gene mutation in XLA; typically IL2RG gene mutation in SCID). Moreover, flow cytometry would show a deficiency of B cells (rather than Th17 cells) in CVID and XLA, and a deficiency of B cells and all classes of T cells (not just Th17 cells) in SCID. None of these conditions are associated with cold abscesses, facial dysmorphism, or eosinophilia.
questions.hint: Facial dysmorphism, eosinophilia, and decreased Th17 levels indicate that this patient has Job syndrome.

questions.text:

Over the past 2 years, he has also had 7 episodes of fever and purulent nasal discharge, each lasting for 5 to 7 days. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs, and takes no medications. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is in moderate distress. His temperature is 38.6ºC (101.5ºF), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. A peripheral blood smear shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows right lower lobe consolidation. An HIV test is negative. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pathological fractures are common in patients with autosomal dominant hyper-IgE syndrome (Job syndrome) because of decreased bone density caused by increased bone reabsorption. Job syndrome can also manifest with recurrent sinopulmonary infections due to a defect in neutrophil chemotaxis. This patient, however, has decreased rather than increased serum levels of IgE. Moreover, patients with Job syndrome usually present with coarse facies (e.g., broad nose, frontal bossing) and other dermatologic findings (e.g., severe eczema, noninflamed skin abscesses).

B) INCORRECT:

Retinal hypopigmentation due to oculocutaneous albinism can be seen in patients with Chédiak-Higashi syndrome, which also manifests with recurrent pyogenic infections. However, normal rather than low serum immunoglobulin levels are expected in these patients. Moreover, Chédiak-Higashi syndrome usually manifests with neutropenia and the peripheral blood smear typically shows giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Inclusion bodies (examples indicated by arrows) and polymorphous nuclei (green overlay) can be seen within the leukocytes.

These findings are consistent with Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

CVID is associated with an increased risk of developing autoimmune disorders (e.g., immune thrombocytopenia, rheumatoid arthritis, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, autoimmune thyroiditis, vitiligo) as a result of immune system dysregulation. Patients with CVID are also at increased risk of developing lymphoma, gastric cancer, and bronchiectasis.

Selective IgA deficiency and Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome are other congenital immunodeficiencies associated with an increased risk of developing autoimmune disorders.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebellar ataxia is seen in patients with ataxia-telangiectasia, which can also manifest with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and low serum levels of IgA, IgE, and IgG. However, low serum levels of IgM are not expected. Moreover, the age of onset is generally 6–18 months and ataxia-telangiectasia typically manifests with spider angiomas and other neurological features (e.g., chorea, dystonia, myoclonic jerks, oculomotor apraxia).

E) INCORRECT:

Left heart failure due to hypoplastic left heart syndrome can occur in patients with DiGeorge syndrome, which can also manifest with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and low serum IgM levels. However, low serum levels of IgA, IgG, and IgE are not expected. Moreover, this patient does not have other typical findings seen in patients with DiGeorge syndrome, such as facial anomalies (i.e., dysplastic ears, micrognathia, cleft palate), features of hypocalcemia (e.g., tetany), and an absent thymic shadow on chest x-ray.
questions.hint: This patient's history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections in combination with low serum levels of all immunoglobulins suggests common variable immunodeficiency (CVID).

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever, irritability, and a purulent discharge from his left ear. Three months ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for pneumonia. Family history is remarkable for recurrent pulmonary infections in his maternal uncle. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 36/min. Examination of the oral cavity shows hypoplastic adenoids without exudate. There is purulent discharge coming out of the left auditory meatus. Serum studies show decreased levels of IgG, IgM, and IgA antibodies. Flow cytometry shows markedly low levels of B cells and high levels of T cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

DiGeorge syndrome manifests with recurrent infections, but the infections are usually caused by viruses and/or fungi (e.g., Pneumocystis jirovecii) and are not pyogenic. Moreover, patients with DiGeorge syndrome typically present with other associated features, like cardiac anomalies, dysmorphic facies (e.g., prominent nasal bridge, micrognathia, dysplastic ears), cleft palate, and features of hypocalcemia (due to hypoparathyroidism), none of which is seen here. Finally, flow cytometry in patients with DiGeorge syndrome shows decreased rather than increased levels of T cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) can manifest with recurrent pyogenic infections (e.g., pneumonia, otitis media) and hypogammaglobulinemia, both of which are seen here. However, the typical age of onset for CVID is 20–40 years. In addition, flow cytometry would show subsets of normal B cells and T cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) can manifest with recurrent infections, but the infections are typically opportunistic rather than pyogenic (e.g., otitis media, pneumonia). The most common infections in SCID include bacterial diarrhea, chronic candidiasis, and viral and protozoal infections, none of which is seen here. Moreover, flow cytometry typically shows absent T cells rather than the increased levels seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) can manifest with recurrent pyogenic infections and low levels of IgG and IgM, both of which are seen here. Furthermore, this condition occurs primarily in male individuals. However, WAS is associated with increased IgA antibodies and decreased T cells on flow cytometry. Moreover, patients with WAS typically present with eczema and purpura, neither of which is seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Bruton agammaglobulinemia (X-linked agammaglobulinemia, or XLA) is characterized by recurrent pyogenic infections (e.g., pneumonia, otitis media), especially with encapsulated bacteria, hypoplastic lymphoid tissue (e.g., adenoids), low or absent serum immunoglobulins, and low levels of B cells. Affected individuals typically present after 3–6 months of age because of a drop in maternal IgG levels and the resultant waning of passive immunity. Because this condition is X-linked, mainly male individuals are affected. Treatment includes immunoglobulin replacement with IV immunoglobulin and prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial infections.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

F) INCORRECT:

Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy (THI) typically manifests with recurrent pyogenic infections (e.g., pneumonia, otitis media) and hypogammaglobulinemia in infants after 6 months of age. However, THI is associated with normal rather than decreased levels of B cells on flow cytometry.
questions.hint: This child's hypogammaglobulinemia and low levels of B cells, together with a family history of recurrent pulmonary infections in his maternal uncle, suggest a congenital B-cell immunodeficiency.

questions.text: Twenty minutes after undergoing a platelet transfusion, a 15-year-old boy develops chest tightness and dyspnea. He was admitted to the hospital 3 hours ago for an uncontrolled nosebleed. His medical history is remarkable for several episodes of sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections. He appears to be in acute distress. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 28/min and labored, and blood pressure is 87/60 mm Hg. Expiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. This patient's most likely underlying condition predisposes him most to infection with which of the following microorganisms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infections with encapsulated bacteria like Escherichia coli are associated with B-cell defects. B cells produce immunoglobulins necessary for opsonization (e.g., IgG) and complement fixation (e.g., IgM), both of which are essential processes in the destruction of encapsulated bacteria. However, IgA is not involved in opsonization or complement fixation. Although this patient has a humoral immunodeficiency, only the IgA secreting B cells are affected, which does not increase his risk of developing encapsulated bacterial infections.

B) CORRECT:

Defective IgA secreting B cells in patients with SIgAD leads to an impeded formation of secretory IgA at mucosal surfaces (e.g., respiratory epithelium, gastrointestinal tract), which is a vital component of mucosal immunity. Low levels of secretory IgA in patients with SIgAD increase the risk of Giardia lamblia infection and sinopulmonary infections (e.g., due to H. influenzae, S. pneumoniae). In addition, patients with SIgAD are at an increased risk of autoimmune diseases like immune thrombocytopenia. This patient's uncontrolled nose bleed that required a platelet transfusion may indicate that he has autoimmune thrombocytopenia. Low serum IgA with normal IgG and IgM concentrations confirms the diagnosis of SIgAD.

In rare cases, individuals with SIgAD may form anti-IgA antibodies, which increase their risk of developing anaphylaxis following a transfusion with blood products containing IgA (e.g., platelet transfusions, RBC transfusions). If transfusions are necessary, the patient should first be screened for anti-IgA antibodies, and transfusion should be prepared from another IgA-deficient individual. If RBC transfusions are required, they can be saline-washed.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased susceptibility to enteroviral infections, such as coxsackievirus, is commonly seen in individuals with Bruton agammaglobulinemia (X-linked agammaglobulinemia; XLA), which causes a complete deficiency of mature B cells. XLA primarily occurs in boys and can manifest with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, both of which are seen here. However, symptoms of XLA typically develop between 3 and 6 months of age when maternal IgG levels in fetal serum start to decrease. Also, anaphylactic reactions to blood products are not consistent with features of XLA. Coxsackievirus infections are not commonly associated with SIgAD.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

D) INCORRECT:

Increased susceptibility to viral infections, such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), is usually a sign of impaired T-cell function. CMV infections with severe manifestations (e.g., CMV pneumonia, CMV retinitis) are most commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those with HIV infection, organ transplant recipients), not in those with humoral immunodeficiencies like SIgAD.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic fungal infections caused by Aspergillus fumigatus, Candida, or Mucor are more likely to occur in patients with neutropenia due to hematological malignancy or side effects of chemotherapy (e.g., mucositis, myelosuppression). Although febrile neutropenia can manifest with shock, the absence of fever and acute onset of symptoms following a platelet transfusion are not typical features of a septic shock. Moreover, the long-standing history of infections in this patient points towards a congenital immunodeficiency disorder.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with terminal complement deficiencies (C5–C9) are more susceptible to infections with Neisseria meningitidis due to failure of formation of membrane attack complex. Although meningococcal sepsis can manifest with shock, this patient's hemodynamic instability is most likely due to an anaphylactic reaction to the platelet transfusion. Moreover, this patient's recurrent gastrointestinal and sinopulmonary infections along with anaphylactic reactions to blood products are not seen in patients with terminal complement deficiencies.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of anaphylaxis (chest tightness, dyspnea, wheezing, tachycardia, hypotension) following a platelet transfusion, which in conjunction with a history of recurrent sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections is suggestive of selective IgA deficiency (SIgAD).

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because she has a fever for the last 2 days and developed a rash this morning. The patient had 2 previous hospital admissions for similar symptoms at the ages of 13 and 15 years. There is no family history of serious illness. Immunizations are up-to-date. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 105/71 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a diffuse petechial rash over the abdomen and both legs. There is neck rigidity and bilateral flexion of the hips and knees with passive flexion of the neck. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of blood cultures are pending. A lumbar puncture is performed. Cerebrospinal fluid culture grows Neisseria meningitidis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dihydrorhodamine test is used in the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). Recurrent infections are typical of CGD and are usually caused by catalase-positive organisms. Although Neisseria spp. are catalase-positive, most patients with CGD develop infections from Staphylococcus aureus, Aspergillus spp., Burkholderia cepacia, Nocardia spp., and Serratia marcescens. While skin involvement is common in patients with CGD, CGD typically manifests with skin granulomas, cellulitis, and skin abscesses, not a diffuse petechial rash. Furthermore, meningitis is not characteristic of CGD.

B) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the absolute neutrophil count is indicated in patients with congenital neutropenia (CN), which is characterized by recurrent bacterial infections. However, most infections are caused by Streptococcus and Staphylococcus and typically include gingivitis, oral ulcers, respiratory and skin infections, and otitis media, not meningitis. Furthermore, symptoms usually develop soon after birth, whereas this patient's first infectious episode occurred at the age of 13 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry can be used for the diagnosis of immunodeficiencies like Bruton agammaglobulinemia (BA). Recurrent infections (e.g., pneumonia, meningitis) with encapsulated organisms (e.g., Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae) are typical of BA. However, BA is an X-linked recessive condition that mainly occurs in male infants. Symptoms typically develop at the age of 3–6 months, when maternal IgG levels in the serum decrease.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

D) CORRECT:

Individuals with terminal complement deficiency (C5–C9) have impaired formation of the membrane attack complex, which leads to recurrent pyogenic infections with Neisseria spp. and possibly sepsis. CH50 assay is the preferred initial test in suspected complement pathway deficiency and it typically shows low or undetectable CH50 titers in affected patients. Because there is no definitive treatment, patients with terminal complement deficiency should be aware of the high risk of life-threatening infections, and they require all routine bacterial and viral vaccines (most importantly meningococcal vaccines). Antibiotic prophylaxis may also be considered in individuals with recurrent infections despite complete vaccinations.

See “Overview of congenital immunodeficiency disorders” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum IgE levels is typically performed in patients with suspected hyper-IgE syndrome (Job syndrome), which is characterized by recurrent bacterial infections. However, most infections are due to Staphylococcus aureus and Candida albicans, not Neisseria meningitidis. Although skin involvement is common in Job syndrome, it typically manifests with a severely pruritic and eczematous rash, cold skin abscesses, and/or cellulitis rather than a diffuse petechial rash. Furthermore, this patient does not have other characteristic features of Job syndrome, such as coarse facies, retained primary teeth, and fractures due to decreased bone density.
questions.hint: Fever, petechial rash, meningeal signs, and positive CSF culture for N. meningitidis are consistent with meningococcal meningitis. Recurrent meningococcal infections are highly characteristic of this patient's condition.

Interferon gamma (IFN-γ), primarily secreted by Th1 and NK cells, is used to treat certain immunodeficiency disorders, such as IL-12 receptor deficiency and chronic granulomatous disease. However, since IFN-γ levels are typically normal in B cell immunodeficiencies such as XLA, interferon gamma administration is not indicated in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) is characterized by a Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene defect, leading to impaired maturation of B lymphocytes, resulting in low or absent B cell levels and reduced immunoglobulin levels of all classes. Because this condition follows an X-linked recessive inheritance, XLA primarily affects male individuals. Symptoms typically develop at 3–6 months of age when the birthing parent's IgG levels in the infant's serum start to decrease. Treatment of XLA focuses on the prevention of infections and involves the administration of IV immunoglobulins and prophylactic antibiotics.

Although treatment of congenital B cell immunodeficiencies and mixed immunodeficiencies almost always includes IV immunoglobulins, their use is not recommended in the treatment of selective IgA deficiency because of the risk of allergic reactions. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is a potentially curative therapy for mixed immunodeficiency disorders, certain T-cell disorders, and phagocytic deficiencies, but is rarely used to treat pure B-cell immunodeficiencies like XLA.
