questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defect in the T-cell CD40 ligand causes hyper-IgM syndrome, where IgM is elevated, and IgG, IgA, and IgE are low. This patient has low levels of all immunoglobulins and reduced CD19+ B cells, indicating a primary B-cell development defect rather than impaired class-switch recombination.

B) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the interleukin-2 receptor gamma chain causes X-linked severe combined immunodeficiency (X-SCID), characterized by low T and natural killer cells, with normal or elevated B cells. This patient's normal T cell numbers and reduced B cells, along with low immunoglobulin levels, suggest a B-cell development defect, not X-SCID.

C) INCORRECT:

A mutation affecting microtubule function in phagocytes is associated with Chediak-Higashi syndrome, characterized by impaired degranulation and chemotaxis, partial albinism, and giant granules in neutrophils. This patient's findings indicate a humoral immunodeficiency, not a phagocytic disorder.

D) CORRECT:

X-linked agammaglobulinemia results from a mutation in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene, crucial for B-cell maturation in the bone marrow. This mutation leads to a significant reduction in circulating CD19+ B cells and low levels of all immunoglobulin classes. Patients are prone to recurrent bacterial infections after maternal IgG wanes. The absence of tonsils and lymph nodes reflects impaired B-cell maturation and secondary lymphoid tissue development, consistent with the clinical and laboratory findings in this patient.

Key learning point: X-linked agammaglobulinemia is characterized by low serum immunoglobulin levels, few B cells, and recurrent bacterial infections, typically affecting males due to its X-linked inheritance.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic by his mother for evaluation of recurrent infections and easy bruising. He has been hospitalized three times for severe skin and respiratory infections, which improved with antibiotics. On examination, he has sparse silvery hair, hypopigmented skin, and diffuse petechiae. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 80 g/L (115–155), white blood cell count of 3.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5), and platelet count of 45 × 109/L (130–380). A peripheral blood smear reveals giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defective NADPH oxidase results in chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which typically manifests in infancy with recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus, Aspergillus spp., Burkholderia cepacia, and Serratia marcescens. Common features of CGD include lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive, none of which are seen in this patient. Partial albinism, coagulation defects, pancytopenia, and giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets are not seen in CGD.

B) CORRECT:

A defective lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST) is the underlying pathophysiology of Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS). It causes a fusion defect in granules of all cells, resulting in giant intracellular granules. In addition, a microtubule polymerization dysfunction impairs the fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, which affects the normal immune response of neutrophils and monocytes. CHS patients who survive up to adolescence or longer (∼ 10%) develop severe defects of the peripheral and central nervous system (e.g., neuropathies, intellectual decline, dementia, ataxia).

Key learning point: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is caused by a defect in the LYST gene, leading to impaired lysosomal trafficking, giant cytoplasmic granules in leukocytes, partial albinism, and recurrent infections.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Inclusion bodies (examples indicated by arrows) and polymorphous nuclei (green overlay) can be seen within the leukocytes.

These findings are consistent with Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

A defective CD40 ligand causes hyper-IgM syndrome type 1 (HIGM1), a disorder characterized by impaired class-switch recombination that manifests in infancy with recurrent infections with encapsulated bacteria and opportunistic infections. Common features of this disorder also include chronic diarrhea from Cryptosporidium infection and failure to thrive. Sinopulmonary infections are a common manifestation of HIGM1, but recurrent skin infections, partial albinism, diffuse petechiae, pancytopenia, and a blood smear finding of giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets are not.

D) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the WAS gene is the underlying cause of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which can manifest in infancy with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura and recurrent infections, especially with encapsulated bacteria and opportunistic pathogens. Severe eczema, which is not present in this patient, is a characteristic finding of the disorder. Partial albinism, coagulation defects, and giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets are not seen in WAS, nor is pancytopenia or a blood smear finding of giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets.

E) INCORRECT:

A defect in the Bruton tyrosine kinase gene (BTK) is responsible for X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), a primary humoral immunodeficiency characterized by susceptibility to infection with encapsulated bacteria and certain viruses (especially enteroviruses). XLA typically first manifests at 3–6 months of age with recurrent respiratory infections and otitis media because infants generally retain passively acquired maternal antibodies up until this point. Recurrent skin infections, partial albinism, and pancytopenia are not features of BTK, nor is the blood smear finding of giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets.
questions.hint: The infant's blood smear shows giant granules in granulocytes and platelets, a characteristic finding of Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS). This condition is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder characterized by recurrent pyogenic infections (involving the skin, respiratory tract, and mucous membranes), partial albinism with various degrees of skin hypopigmentation and silvery-white hair, pancytopenia, and mild coagulation defects that result in easy bruising and mucosal bleeding in early childhood.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-month-old boy in the emergency department who has a 2-day history of fever, irritability, and purulent discharge from his left ear. Three months ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for pneumonia. His family history is notable for recurrent pulmonary infections in his maternal uncle. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.7°C, pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 36/min. Examination of the oral cavity reveals hypoplastic adenoids without exudate. There is purulent discharge from the left auditory meatus. Serum studies show decreased levels of IgG, IgM, and IgA. Flow cytometry reveals markedly low levels of B cells and high levels of T cells. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bruton agammaglobulinemia (X-linked agammaglobulinemia, or XLA) is characterized by recurrent pyogenic infections (e.g., pneumonia, otitis media), especially with encapsulated bacteria, hypoplastic lymphoid tissue (e.g., adenoids), low or absent serum immunoglobulins, and low levels of B cells. Affected individuals typically present after 3–6 months of age because of a drop in maternal IgG levels and the resultant waning of passive immunity. Because this condition is X-linked, mainly male individuals are affected. Treatment includes immunoglobulin replacement with IV immunoglobulin and prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial infections.

Key learning point: X-linked agammaglobulinemia presents after 3–6 months of age with recurrent bacterial infections, low immunoglobulins, absent B cells, and hypoplastic lymphoid tissue, and primarily affects males due to its X-linked inheritance.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

B) INCORRECT:

Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy (THI) typically manifests with recurrent pyogenic infections (e.g., pneumonia, otitis media) and hypogammaglobulinemia in infants after 6 months of age. However, THI is associated with normal rather than decreased levels of B cells on flow cytometry.

C) INCORRECT:

DiGeorge syndrome manifests with recurrent infections, but the infections are usually caused by viruses and/or fungi (e.g., Pneumocystis jirovecii) and are not pyogenic. Moreover, patients with DiGeorge syndrome typically present with other associated features, like cardiac anomalies, dysmorphic facies (e.g., prominent nasal bridge, micrognathia, dysplastic ears), cleft palate, and features of hypocalcemia (due to hypoparathyroidism), none of which is seen here. Finally, flow cytometry in patients with DiGeorge syndrome shows decreased rather than increased levels of T cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) can manifest with recurrent infections, but the infections are typically opportunistic rather than pyogenic (e.g., otitis media, pneumonia). The most common infections in SCID include bacterial diarrhea, chronic candidiasis, and viral and protozoal infections, none of which is seen here. Moreover, flow cytometry typically shows absent T cells rather than the increased levels seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) can manifest with recurrent pyogenic infections (e.g., pneumonia, otitis media) and hypogammaglobulinemia, both of which are seen here. However, the typical age of onset for CVID is 20–40 years. In addition, flow cytometry would show subsets of normal B cells and T cells.
questions.hint: This child's hypogammaglobulinemia and low levels of B cells, together with a family history of recurrent pulmonary infections in his maternal uncle, suggest a congenital B-cell immunodeficiency.

questions.text: Twenty minutes after receiving a platelet transfusion, a 15-year-old boy develops chest tightness and dyspnea. He was admitted to the hospital 3 hours ago for an uncontrolled nosebleed. His medical history includes multiple episodes of sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections. He appears to be in acute distress. His temperature is 36.7°C, pulse is 115/min, respirations are 28/min and labored, and blood pressure is 87/60 mm Hg. Expiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. Which one of the following microorganisms is he most predisposed to infection with, given his underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with terminal complement deficiencies (C5–C9) are more susceptible to infections with Neisseria meningitidis due to failure of formation of membrane attack complex. Although meningococcal sepsis can manifest with shock, this patient's hemodynamic instability is most likely due to an anaphylactic reaction to the platelet transfusion. Moreover, this patient's recurrent gastrointestinal and sinopulmonary infections along with anaphylactic reactions to blood products are not seen in patients with terminal complement deficiencies.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased susceptibility to viral infections, such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), is usually a sign of impaired T-cell function. CMV infections with severe manifestations (e.g., CMV pneumonia, CMV retinitis) are most commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those with HIV infection, organ transplant recipients), not in those with humoral immunodeficiencies like SIgAD.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic fungal infections caused by Aspergillus fumigatus, Candida, or Mucor are more likely to occur in patients with neutropenia due to hematological malignancy or side effects of chemotherapy (e.g., mucositis, myelosuppression). Although febrile neutropenia can manifest with shock, the absence of fever and acute onset of symptoms following a platelet transfusion are not typical features of a septic shock. Moreover, the long-standing history of infections in this patient points towards a congenital immunodeficiency disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Infections with encapsulated bacteria like Escherichia coli are associated with B-cell defects. B cells produce immunoglobulins necessary for opsonization (e.g., IgG) and complement fixation (e.g., IgM), both of which are essential processes in the destruction of encapsulated bacteria. However, IgA is not involved in opsonization or complement fixation. Although this patient has a humoral immunodeficiency, only the IgA secreting B cells are affected, which does not increase his risk of developing encapsulated bacterial infections.

E) CORRECT:

Defective IgA secreting B cells in patients with SIgAD leads to an impeded formation of secretory IgA at mucosal surfaces (e.g., respiratory epithelium, gastrointestinal tract), which is a vital component of mucosal immunity. Low levels of secretory IgA in patients with SIgAD increase the risk of Giardia lamblia infection and sinopulmonary infections (e.g., due to H. influenzae, S. pneumoniae). In addition, patients with SIgAD are at an increased risk of autoimmune diseases like immune thrombocytopenia. This patient's uncontrolled nose bleed that required a platelet transfusion may indicate that he has autoimmune thrombocytopenia. Low serum IgA with normal IgG and IgM concentrations confirms the diagnosis of SIgAD.

In rare cases, individuals with SIgAD may form anti-IgA antibodies, which increase their risk of developing anaphylaxis following a transfusion with blood products containing IgA (e.g., platelet transfusions, RBC transfusions). If transfusions are necessary, the patient should first be screened for anti-IgA antibodies, and transfusion should be prepared from another IgA-deficient individual. If RBC transfusions are required, they can be saline-washed.

Key learning point: Selective IgA deficiency increases susceptibility to recurrent sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections, particularly with Giardia lamblia, due to impaired mucosal immunity.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of anaphylaxis (chest tightness, dyspnea, wheezing, tachycardia, hypotension) following a platelet transfusion, which in conjunction with a history of recurrent sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections is suggestive of selective IgA deficiency (SIgAD).

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of fever, productive cough, and shortness of breath. Since birth, he has had multiple respiratory infections requiring treatment with antibiotics. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is in the 10th percentile for height and weight. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.3°F). Examination detects diffuse bilateral wheezing and cervical lymphadenopathy. Flow cytometric analysis of a serum sample from the patient fails to fluoresce after incubation with dihydrorhodamine. This patient is at greatest risk of infection with which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecium is a gram-positive coccus (group D streptococcus) that is part of the natural flora of the gastrointestinal tract. E. faecium is catalase negative. The lack of catalase allows bacterially produced hydrogen peroxide to be utilized by host phagocytes as a means of producing bactericidal reactive oxygen species. Therefore, patients with CGD do not have an innate susceptibility to catalase-negative organisms such as E. faecium.

B) INCORRECT:

Actinomyces israelii is a gram-positive, rod-shaped filamentous bacteria that causes orofacial infections. It is catalase negative. The lack of catalase allows bacterially produced hydrogen peroxide to be utilized by host phagocytes as a means of producing bactericidal reactive oxygen species. Therefore, patients with CGD do not have an innate susceptibility to catalase-negative organisms such as A. israelii.

C) CORRECT:

Serratia marcescens is a gram-negative, catalase-positive organism that commonly affects patients who have CGD. CGD is characterized by defective superoxide production from neutrophils and macrophages. Consequently, host neutrophils rely on the hydrogen peroxide produced by bacteria rather than on oxygen as a precursor to bactericidal reactive oxygen species. Catalase-producing organisms such as Serratia marcescens, however, are able to metabolize their own hydrogen peroxide. This deprives CGD host neutrophils of the substrate needed to form reactive oxygen species, predisposing patients to infection with such bacteria.

Other important catalase-positive organisms that commonly cause infections in CGD include S. aureus, Nocardia spp., Aspergillus, and B. cepacia. Patients with CGD require lifelong prophylactic antibiotics (TMP-SMX for catalase-positive infections). IFN-γ therapy can also reduce the incidence of serious infection. Bone marrow transplant is the definitive treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive, encapsulated diplococcus that is catalase-negative. The lack of catalase allows bacterially produced hydrogen peroxide to be utilized by host phagocytes as a means of producing bactericidal reactive oxygen species. Therefore, patients with CGD do not have an innate susceptibility to catalase-negative organisms such as S. pneumoniae.

E) INCORRECT:

Clostridioides difficile is a gram-positive, spore-forming bacillus that is implicated in pseudomembranous colitis. It is catalase negative. The lack of catalase allows bacterially produced hydrogen peroxide to be utilized by host phagocytes as a means of producing bactericidal reactive oxygen species. Therefore, patients with CGD do not have an innate susceptibility to catalase-negative organisms such as C. difficile.

F) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes is a gram-positive organism frequently responsible for skin and soft tissue infections and acute pharyngitis, among others. S. pyogenes is catalase negative. The lack of catalase allows bacterially produced hydrogen peroxide to be utilized by host phagocytes as a means of producing bactericidal reactive oxygen species. Therefore, patients with CGD do not have an innate susceptibility to catalase-negative organisms such as S. pyogenes.
questions.hint: Recurrent bacterial infections in a child raise suspicion for a congenital immunodeficiency. This patient's abnormal dihydrorhodamine flow cytometry test indicates decreased NADPH oxidase activity, which suggests chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). Individuals with CGD are particularly susceptible to infection with catalase-positive organisms.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of white discoloration of the tongue. She has had similar, recurrent episodes over the past 5 years. Examination shows white plaques on the tongue that easily scrape off and thick, cracked fingernails with white discoloration. KOH preparation of a tongue scraping shows budding yeasts with pseudohyphae. This patient's condition is most likely caused by decreased activity of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

B cells, which differentiate into plasma cells or memory B cells, are critical to the humoral immune response. Conditions associated with a defect in B cell function (e.g., x-linked agammaglobulinemia, selective IgA deficiency, common variable immunodeficiency) are typically associated with recurrent infections by encapsulated pathogens. This patient's tongue scraping shows evidence of Candida infection, which is associated with a defect in the cell-mediated immune response rather than the humoral response.

B) INCORRECT:

Complement components C5–9 (terminal complement) are involved in the final steps of complement system activation and form the membrane attack complex. Deficiency of these proteins is associated with recurrent Neisseria bacteremia, which manifests as fever, sepsis, meningitis, and a purpuric rash. This patient lacks these systemic symptoms and the skin scraping shows a fungal rather than bacterial infection.

C) CORRECT:

T cells play a key role in immunity against fungi and viruses. T cell dysfunction is responsible for a variety of immune deficiencies, including chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis (CMCC), which typically manifests with noninvasive Candida albicans infections of the skin, mucous membranes, and nails. Examples of congenital T-cell immunodeficiencies include DiGeorge syndrome, Hyper IgE syndrome, IL-12 deficiency, severe combined immunodeficiency, and Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. CMCC with features of autoimmune disease is typically caused by a deficiency in the AIRE protein, IL-17, or IL-17 receptors.

D) INCORRECT:

Complement components C1–4 (early complement) are involved in the initial steps of complement system activation. Deficiency of these proteins predisposes patients to SLE and recurrent sinus or respiratory tract infections by capsulated pathogens. This patient's infection is caused by Candida, which is a non-capsulated yeast.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased neutrophil number or activity predisposes patients to infection with catalase-positive organisms such as Candida, but patients would develop disseminated candidiasis (fungemia), characterized by features of sepsis (e.g., fever, hypotension). Mucocutaneous candidiasis without signs of systemic infection suggests a defect in a different component of the immune system.
questions.hint: A KOH preparation of a tongue scraping that shows budding yeasts with pseudohyphae confirms the diagnosis of oral candidiasis (thrush). This woman's nail findings are suspicious for onychomycosis. Chronic and/or recurrent, localized candidal infections of the oral cavity and nails are common features of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 2-day history of poor feeding and lethargy. He was born at term and has had three episodes of bilateral otitis media since birth. Umbilical cord separation occurred at the age of 8 weeks. He is at the 30th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F) and blood pressure is 58/36 mm Hg. Physical examination shows white oral patches and confluent scaly erythematous skin lesions in the groin. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 41,300/mm3 (92% segmented neutrophils and 8% lymphocytes) and a platelet count of 224,000/mm3. Blood cultures at 20°C (68°F) grow catalase-positive yeast cells. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defective CD40 ligand is the underlying mechanism of type 1 hyper-IgM syndrome, which typically manifests with recurrent infections during the first 2 years of life. However, neutropenia rather than neutrophilia is typically seen, and patients often show failure to thrive. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.

B) CORRECT:

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD1) is caused by an autosomal recessive defect in CD18 (beta-2 integrin), which prevents leukocyte migration to the site of infection. As a result, patients have recurrent mucocutaneous infections that can progress to sepsis and a characteristic absence of pus or neutrophils at the site of infection. Other features of the condition include poor wound healing with large skin ulcers, delayed separation of the umbilical cord due to omphalitis, and severe periodontitis/gingivitis. A very high neutrophil count (as high as 100,000/mm3 during active infection) is seen because neutrophil activation and recruitment of neutrophils from the non-circulating pool occurs. However, neutrophils are unable to extravasate into tissues, causing pooling within the circulation.

LAD1 is diagnosed using flow cytometric measurement of surface molecules such as CD11b or CD18. The treatment for mild to moderate cases is mainly supportive, with early treatment of infections and prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole if needed, but severe cases require definitive therapy with hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

C) INCORRECT:

A defect in the interleukin-2 receptor subunit gamma gene (IL2RG) is the most common mutation associated with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), which can manifest soon after birth with recurrent episodes of otitis media, candidiasis, and sepsis. However, patients would also typically show failure to thrive and have a history of chronic diarrhea. A CBC, moreover, would reveal a low absolute lymphocyte count (< 1000/mm3). Delayed umbilical cord separation would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

A defect in Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) is responsible for X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which may result in recurrent otitis media from infection with extracellular bacteria such as S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae. However, infants with B-cell defects such as XLA typically do not develop symptoms before 3–6 months because they generally retain passively acquired maternal antibodies up to this age. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected. Moreover, candidiasis is more commonly seen in defects involving T cells and granulocytes than in isolated primary defects of antibody production such as XLA.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

E) INCORRECT:

Defective NADPH oxidase results in chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which may manifest in infancy with candidiasis (since C. albicans is catalase-positive) and neutrophilia during episodes of infection. However, these infections tend to remain localized, and sepsis is not as common as in other primary immune deficiency syndromes. Other pathognomonic features of CGD include GI obstruction and urinary retention caused by granulomas. Delayed umbilical cord separation would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Defective microtubules due to a loss of function of the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST) is the underlying pathophysiology of Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS), which can result in systemic candidiasis. However, patients with CHS would have neutropenia, not neutrophilia. Features such as oculocutaneous albinism and/or ocular motility disorders (e.g., strabismus, nystagmus) would also be present. Delayed umbilical cord separation would not be expected.

G) INCORRECT:

A defectively organized actin cytoskeleton due to a mutation in the WAS gene is the underlying cause of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), which can manifest in infancy with recurrent otitis media as well as scaly erythematous lesions in the diaper area due to atopic dermatitis. However, the absence of thrombocytopenia on a CBC essentially rules out WAS. Delayed umbilical cord separation would also not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient has mucocutaneous candidiasis (e.g., white oral patches, diaper rash) and features of septic shock (e.g., fever, hypotension, tachycardia) due to disseminated Candida infection. In combination with delayed separation of the umbilical cord, these features suggest leukocyte adhesion deficiency.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy with a history of multiple hospitalizations for fever and infection undergoes immunologic evaluation. Serum CH50 assay shows inappropriately low erythrocyte lysis and further workup confirms C8 deficiency. This patient is at increased risk for recurrent infections with which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Terminal complement deficiencies (C5–C9) impede the formation of the membrane attack complex, which renders affected patients more susceptible to Neisseria bacteremia (e.g., N. meningitidis and N. gonorrhoeae pyogenic infections).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an urethral smear specimen (Gram stain with fuchsin counterstain; high magnification)

The smear shows an abundance of neutrophils recognizable by their typical segmented nuclei and accumulations of diplococci, in the intracellular (within neutrophils; examples indicated by white arrowheads in magnification) and extracellular space (examples indicated by black arrowheads).

This microscopic finding is characteristic of acute gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Diagnosis must be confirmed by cultural isolation and identification of the pathogens.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with an IgA deficiency (e.g., selective IgA deficiency or ataxia-telangiectasia) are at increased risk of Giardia lamblia infection. Giardiasis is not associated with terminal complement deficiency.
Image Description:

Colorized scanning electron micrograph

The protozoal parasite Giardia lamblia (brown) appears here during a late stage of replication, which explains the heart shape. Giardia lamblia uses flagella (purple) for motility. Therefore, it classified as a flagellate. It is the causative agent of giardiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Fungal infections, including Candida, are associated with impaired T-cell immunity and IL-17 defects. These can be detected by the absence of a reaction to cutaneous application of Candida antigen, or absent T-cell proliferation in vitro, but will not influence CH50 assay. Candida infections are not associated with terminal complement deficiency.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.

D) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii infections are associated with hyper-IgM syndrome and significant T-cell dysfunction (e.g., in HIV). Hyper-IgM syndrome is characterized by decreased levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE, while IgM levels may be normal or increased. It does not influence CH50 assay, and Pneumocystis infections are not associated with terminal complement deficiency.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of alveolar tissue infected with P. jirovecii (Grocott's methenamine silver stain, high magnification)

The cysts of this fungus are located within the alveoli together with an inflammatory exudate (red overlay). The cyst walls are stained black in this silver stain.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased susceptibility to Nocardia and other catalase-positive species is seen in granulocyte deficiencies such as chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). CGD can be detected with flow cytometry (the tetrazolium dye reduction test is obsolete) but does not have an effect on CH50 assay. Nocardia infection is not associated with terminal complement deficiency.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of bacteria in blood culture (Kinyoun stain)

Clusters of branching, filamentous rods are concentrated in the center.

F) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium infection is associated with decreased interferon gamma and interleukin-12 receptor deficiency. It is not associated with terminal complement deficiency.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin tissue specimen (H&E stain)

Purple-colored and rod-shaped bacilli (arrowheads) can be seen dispersed throughout the specimen.

This appearance is characteristic of mycobacterial species, such as M. tuberculosis.
questions.hint: Vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics are the recommended treatment for patients with terminal complement deficiencies (C5–C9).
